text:
I want anyone reading this to remember that we still have the opportunity to prevent the worst of climate catastrophe if we, as a society, act in time. In the USA, where our per-capita emissions are among the highest in the world, even if it's hard and impractical to live a zero-emissions lifestyle, you can still get involved in several different organizations which are working to lower everyone's emissions through policy changes, and make a huge difference in the grand scheme. Among them are several political flavors to choose from.
There's:
Citizens' Climate Lobby (personal favorite)
350
Extinction Rebellion
Sunrise Movement
RepublicEN
American Conservation Coalition
Climate Leadership Council
and literally dozens more, which you can find by Googling  "American climate organizations"

Also, check out the Podcasts "How to Save a Planet", "No Place Like Home", "A Matter of Degrees", "Outside/In" and more, available on Spotify, if this is really your beat!

We can do this! We must.

text: It is all about you, your loved ones and your offspring who exist in reality and in manifestations of your dreams. I am aware this talk was given out by Dan Miller with a deep concern that he took the initiative to share more than five years ago. Thanks Dan for breaking out of the waiting queue. Five years is like 5 minutes when it comes to the subject of Global Warming. That's not a joke, trust me! We may not feel the difference over our entire life time and not realize our due role to save the planet for our future generations at the moment of our death. The solution of TAX to Dividend proposed by him can be one of several solutions. The less we depend on the government that has many more past and current problems as a bigger burden, the better pragmatic solutions we can devise. It is our joint responsibility as a human team including people old, young, children, male female, rich, poor etc, from the global nation to listen, understand, ponder over, evaluate the situation by a process in our left brain, right brain and heart with due respect to the concern originating people like Dan who have taken the pains to bring out a concern with the genuine quest for a solution. The national boundaries we perceive are not real. Not in the case of Global Warming. Covid-19 has proved this point. Global Warming will not be impacted by social distancing.  So we need to put our heads and hearts together to focus on topics like: minimize deforestation, transition to electric vehicles, encourage or actively take up research and development on hybrid power generation from solar, wind and hydro energy apart from moth-balling all nuclear plants. Nuclear plants do not produce CO2 but these plants produce pollutants heavier than CO2 in effective damage. Trust me, I have performed the lead role as  Station Engineer, in a nuclear plant operation crew in the 80s. Focus on evolving  deserts into forests! It is possible!! We just need to trust and inspire the young potential heroes and experts among us who love to prove their talents in saving the planet - our Mother Earth. I strongly urge and love to invite all concerned on this subject, in the age group of 11 to 111 years, purely for the joy of life on Mother Earth who loves to take care of our offspring, to participate in a brainstorming session some time. text: ¬†@Climate Chat Club¬† Hi Dan. I appreciate your passion and care for this planet. I do care too. The trouble is that the theory of carbon dioxide-induced global warming is not supported by both historical and empirical evidence, the human contribution to atmospheric CO2 is a mere 3% and even if we have 0% man-made CO2 emission, we still have 97% of CO2 from natural sources to contend with. That is, if we assume that higher CO2 and/or higher global mean temperature is bad. Again, there is no evidence of such badness, eg extreme weather conditions. In fact, the contrary may even be true - higher CO2 is good for life on the planet and warmer climates have positive effects on agriculture and human well-being. If you/we advocate throwing trillions of dollars in vain of reversing something which does not need reversing, we know that the real issue is not the environment or human well-being; but it‚Äôs a scheme for a select few to get big money at the expense of the common man.
author: Daniel Lee

text: ¬†@Daniel Lee¬† That's not true. You are confusing the carbon cycle with atmospheric CO2 concentration. In 1880 atmospheric CO2 was about 280 parts per million (ppm) (0.028%) and now it's about 410 ppm (0.041%) and we know that came mostly from burning fossil fuels (we can carbon date the CO2 and we know that it came from underground), plus we know how much fossil fuel we burn and how much CO2 that creates. And as I point out in the talk, we have known the basics of this since the 1800's. I don't know where you are getting your info, but it is not serving you well.
author: Climate Chat Club

text: ¬†@Climate Chat Club¬† Yes Dan, 410 ppm is the present concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere. The 3% that I‚Äôm referring to is the percentage contribution of man-made CO2 by the burning of fossil fuels to the total CO2 emission to the atmosphere. About 97% are from natural sources.
author: Daniel Lee

text: Sure there have been, but nothing like we are seeing now.  The Medieval Warm Period and Little Ice Age were regional changes... sea levels didn't change much.  The current warming (+1¬∫C so far with more on the way) is a global average with much higher warming in the Arctic.  Sea levels are expected to rise 3 feet or more this century with much more after that.  The last time CO2 levels were what they are today (about 410 ppm), sea levels were about 75 feet higher than today... that's where we are heading though it will take hundreds of years to get there.  But even 3 feet will be devastating for hundreds of millions of people.

text: Yes, CO2 IS a needed ingredient for life, but TOO MUCH of a good thing is still too much. The Earth was a lush paradise before we started burning fossil fuels, and CO2 levels had been at or below 300 parts per million for the previous 800,000 years. By increasing atmospheric levels of CO2 almost 50%, humans have warmed the planet, disrupted the climate, made the oceans more acidic, and set in motions hundreds of cascading changes that threaten the web of life our own lives depend on. The last time the Earth warmed this quickly and oceans became this much more acidic this rapidly, over 90% of marine life went extinct as did over 70% of life on land, including everything over 90 pounds. There are hundreds of strategies for healing and cooling the Earth, but it will require a full-transformation of our economy and way of life.  -Karl

text:
"stop being sheep and research it for yourself. OK, well, speaking as a university researcher who has been studying and writing a book about what we are doing to the planet for over a decade, we KNOW that man-made global warming and climate disruption is real, lethal, urgent, and that WE caused it. Multiple lines of evidence confirm human activity is warming the planet--in part through releasing 650 million years of the sun's stored energy and in part by trapping in the atmosphere more and more of the energy the sun bombards the Earth with 24/7.


Despite whatever you have read/heard, a grand solar minimum would only make the Earth .1-.3 degrees Celsius cooler than it would have been... and it only does that temporarily. Human activity has warmed the Earth ~1.1 degrees Celsius (2 degrees Fahrenheit) and will continue warming it more unless we take massive action to reverse the harm we have done to the Earth's systems. 


Many climate models have predicted quite accurately how much added CO2 will warm the Earth by how much, even models from back in the 1980s (even those of Exxon's own scientists predicted global warming quite accurately). 


I wish it weren't true, but it is, and although it's a slow-motion emergency that creeps up on you, it is already causing so much damage (and so much more damaged is already locked in) that it would be cheaper to transform our way of doing things now rather than face the rapidly rising costs of climate-worsened catastrophes. 


Take care.

text:
Is climate change real or false? forget all the scientists and there graphs and figures, just deal with basic physics.

The answer lies in two simple laws of physics.

Physic law one)  

It is physically impossible to endlessly put something into something that is not endless.   Regardless of the size of the limited space there is no exception to this law, if it is a limited space then you cannot endlessly put something into it.

If that limited space as a ecosystem that relies on balance then every species in it must be kept to a acceptable number that, that ecosystem can naturally support.

But that is not what the human species wants to do,  it wants to put an endless amount of people into this limited space and claims it will not damage or upset the natural balance of this limited space. This is because it cannot deal with  population control,  it doesn't have the emotional ability or the intelligence to discuss such a subject . It is why it is living in denial. 

 Physics law two)

It is physically impossible for a stationary object to keep up with something that is constantly moving.  No matter how far a head you put the stationary object of the thing that is moving it will always catch it up and leave it behind.
Now you can always keep moving the stationary object ahead of the thing that's moving, but to do so you will have to have endless space, if you don't have endless space then you are going to come unstuck.

This should tell you, if you are as intelligent as you all claim to be?  it doesn't matter how many homes you build you will never build enough, because the problem will keep coming back as the population keeps growing.

 The quicker the population grows the quicker the problem comes back, so building homes is not the answer.

The answer is to stop the thing that is moving and keep it level with the stationary object then you have solved the problem for ever until the end of time. 

 So if you control the human population and keep it at a sensible level that each landmass can naturally support,  then you don't have problems because you are keeping the human species in balance with its environment. 

These two laws show you that climate change is real because you have a species just mindlessly endlessly multiplying into a space that is not endless, there can only be one outcome from this behaviour. And it is not a good one .

If anybody thinks I am wrong then I challenge you to prove me wrong,  get a limited space like a cup or any other limited space which your daily life is full of, then show me how you can endlessly pour water or anything else into it without it ever overflowing. Without trickery , And I will admit I am wrong.

I will not be losing any sleep, because to do so you will have to break the laws of physics.


Do not listen to scientists  either side,   just use your basic common sense and that should tell you who is right and who is wrong and that simple law of physics that you practice every single day of your life,  so you don't overfill anything.

text:
-CO2 is not a pollutant. It is an essential building block for life on earth.
-Throughout the entire geological record, after life began on earth, life flourished the most when CO2 concentrations were much, much, much higher than now.
-We are currently in a CO2 drought when compared to the history of life on earth.
-CO2 in the atmosphere does not force temperature rises, it FOLLOWS temperature rises in the geological record.
-It was much hotter than now in the 1930s when CO2 concentrations were much lower.
-No heatwave, nor indeed any weather event at all, has been linked to climate change.
-All warming trends reported by government-funded "research" completely disappear when the original, unaltered data are used.
-We are headed toward an ice age currently and ANYTHING that lessens its deadly frigid impact should be embraced.
-Current Climate Science is not science at all. Real science not only accepts but demands criticism and skepticism.
-Science is the process of discovery by hypothesis and experiment, not the intentional programming of computer model results that will attract government funding.
-Current Climate Science is more akin to the rabid following of Jim Jones.
-The climate has continuously changed throughout the entire existence of earth and there is nothing mankind can do about it.
-Tell every wealth redistributor you know to go take a walk in the park and to be grateful that it is still warm.
author: Daniel Ferry

text:
As the third-world economies emerge and world population grows, can we expect citizens to accept draconian measures that change the way they live?¬†
Let‚Äôs ask the tough questions before we force massive lifestyle changes ‚Äî or spend trillions that could otherwise combat world hunger, fight illiteracy, discover new cures, or raise third-world living standards.
For each of the six questions below, let's answer in support of climate change. However, a "no or not sure" is an indicator that massive expenditures or lifestyle changes are not warranted.
1.¬†¬†¬†¬†Is the world warming?¬†Between 1998-2015 there was an 18-year pause in rising temperatures. Some climatologists think a new ice age is more likely to occur. ¬†We are living at the very tail-end of an ~11,000-year warmer inter-glacial period.¬†¬†Massive glaciation is the norm for the earth.
2.¬†¬†¬†¬†Does climate change pose a threat to the planet?¬†Seas are rising ~2mm/year, about 7-9 inches per century. Temperatures increased about 0.7C since 1850. A doubling of CO2 from 400ppm to 800ppm would only lead to another 0.7C increase. How does this¬†make¬†life, as we know it,¬†end in the next 12 years,¬†as some politicians claim?
3.¬†¬†¬†¬†Is climate change being caused by humans?¬†Or is it all part of evolving world cycles, e.g., solar activity? Earth has been much hotter and much cooler. CO2 levels have varied from 180ppm to almost 7,000ppm (last 140M years). The great civilizations flourished in times warmer than today. Greenhouses regularly operate at 1,200ppm. Plants thrive in higher concentrations of CO2; crop yields increase. The earth has been visibly greening the last 30 years!
4.¬†¬†¬†¬†Are there practical things we can do?¬†If we go back to an 18th-century lifestyle, the impact on temperature would be minimal ‚Äî¬†would all trees be cut down just to stay warm? What exactly is ‚ÄúThe Plan‚Äù ‚Äî¬†is there a sensible one? Is it achievable?¬†
5.¬†¬†¬†¬†Are they affordable?¬†Who pays for all this climate change remediation? The U.S. is already $22 trillion in debt. How do we balance this with demands for increases in social programs?
6.¬†¬†¬†¬†Do we have the political will?¬†Are citizens of the world willing to allow our leaders to implement changes that could directly affect our freedoms, pocketbooks, and consumption patterns? Do we need a one-world-government to have the power and authority to enforce the rules? Now, that would be a "real change" worth noting.

¬†@Dan Miller¬† Thanks for that update.

Australian fires are from poor undergrowth management rather than the warming; just talk to the original indigenous peoples of that continent.
The real encouraging thing is that some have really workable solutions to energy needs that are safe and polution free, that are much more efficient than wind and solar farms. I woukd like to suggest you study the new molten salt cooled nuclear, which has the following extraordinary charactristics.
- Can't suffer melt down, it's already molten.
- Walk away safety, self shut down in the event of climbing core temporatures or circulation failure.
- Can burn existing stocks of nuclear waste.
- Energy density per nuclear decay is a million times that of a carbon-hydrogen bond changing to a carbon-oxygen bong in fossil fuel burning.
- 500-600 C heat from the system can be harnessed for other really useful industrial processes.
And so on.
Sadly the picture from the IPCC, stinks of the corrupted aim to frighten and control humanity. Follow the money and power agendas!
Sorry, Dan, but I didn't hear very much in the presentation that rang true. I remain convinced that climate change has several other causes than man made CO2 and that this is a small proportion of total CO2 produced and an even smaller proportion of total greenhouse gasses. The Sun's heat output, cosmic radiation, cloud cover, Earth to Sun distance, precession and tilt, ocean currents are all implicated. They have all been happening for millions of years and trying to reduce or eliminate our hard won industrial environment won't affect the warming rate significantly.
CO2 is absolutely not a pollutant, being colourless, odourless and harmless to all living beings. It's plant food and without it we all die.
My first degree was Biochemistry, Manchester University and carbon fixation was my pet subject. Photosynthesis and that fixing of CO2 by chloroplasts is phenomenally complex chemistry, almost as complex as the chaotic thermodynamics of climate and weather.
Please don't give up trying to find honest truth amid the gale of propaganda.

text: ¬†@Dan Miller¬† Hi Dan.  I live in Alberta Canada.  A couple of day s ago was the winter solstice and we had exactly 8 hours and 4 minutes of sunshine.  Solar is not workable in Canada.  We have a lot of wind power in Alberta, but on any typical day it might provide 2% of the electricity being used.  The only "cleantech" that makes sense in my part of the world is nuclear, although natural gas generated electricity makes a lot of sense too.  Solar and wind appear to be dead ends in Canada although I am prepared to consider evidence which proves otherwise.
author: John Stodalka

text: ¬†@John Stodalka¬† Hi John:  Wind (with storage), hydro, and nuclear would be far safer and less expensive (when all costs are considered) than using fossil fuels in your part of the world.  The bottom line is we must get off fossil fuels ASAP so we need to figure out what the best alternatives are in each region.
author: Dan Miller

text: ¬†@Dan Miller¬† I agree with you on nuclear Dan.   Saskatchewan is right next door to us Albertans, and Cameco which  runs mines in Saskatchewan is the biggest uranium producer in the world.  But we don't have the river systems needed for hydro (unlike Quebec or Manitoba).  We don't get enough sunshine, so solar is a non-starter.  Wind is not the answer for a number of reasons:  damage to bird population, unreliability of the wind itself, storage technology is nowhere near ready and probably never will be,  the production of wind technology, both the batteries and the wind towers, is an environmental disaster, and finally, nobody wants to live beside those damn propellor blades.  Alberta gets 95% + of its electricity from fossil fuels, and that is not going to substantially change in my lifetime (I'm 60) without destroying the living standards of this part of the world.  It is COLD in Canada, and we need to use fossil fuels.  If we follow your "bottom line" we will completely destroy our economy, and I'm sure you are a nice fellow and you don't want that to happen.  All of Canada would have to migrate south.  You'd have to build a wall on your northern border too!
author: John Stodalka

text:
¬†@John Stodalka¬† John:  +4¬∫C of warming -- expected around the end of the century on the path we are on -- will certainly destroy the economy... and civilization too!  While the (older) current generation in Canada will likely escape the really bad impacts of climate change, the following generations will not be so lucky.  So while it may be a bit easier and less expensive (only in the short run) to keep using fossil fuels, I don't believe it's the right thing to do, given that we do have alternatives today that are actually less expensive (in the the short to long run).  You have misconceptions about wind that I'm not going to get into here.  Let's just say that you can use as much wind as is available and back up using fossil fuels (for now) and other techniques shortly.  Storage is available now and the price is dropping rapidly (batteries are currently beating out natural gas for peaker plants).  There are also new grid approaches such as demand response that are in use now and can be deployed on a broader scale for little cost.  And, of course, we could build high voltage transmissions lines for a fraction of the cost of a nuclear plant that can bring Saskatchewan power when it is short and provide power from Saskatchewan when it is plentiful.

I don't make the rules... Mother Nature does.  So let's work to keep a livable climate for our children and future generations.
author: Dan Miller

text: ¬†@Dan Miller¬† Dan, if environmentalists (I presume you would accept the designation for yourself) force Canadians in a cold climate to abandon fossil fuel, you ARE making the rules.  The populace will not accept a reduction in their standard of living.    There will be a serious political struggle , mainly because  a solid argument can be made that the risks associated with abandoning fossil fuels are greater than the ones associated with a slight temperature rise.  You can speculate about a 4 centigrade increase (which would actually be a blessing for Canada), but it is nothing more a speculative guess by climatologists.    I read somewhere that Al Gore has been wrong on 51 of his predictions!   I've seen it argued persuasively that we are at the end of a 12,000 year interglacial period, and it is more likely we will be cooling in the future, descending into another 90,000 year ice age.  Where I live, there was 1.5 miles of ice a short 18,000 years ago.  Ocean levels have risen 400 feet in the past 18,000 years, nothing to do with mankind burning fossil fuels.  I believe these theories are accepted by most geologists, but they certainly aren't  common knowledge or often referred to in the hysteria over climate.  I also find that when I mention these geological suppositions to family members over Xmas dinner, they aren't so concerned anymore about the "climate emergency."  Essential knowledge about geology needs to become part of the public discourse on climate as a necessary blowback against the climate hysteria that has emerged in the past few years.  It is intellectually dishonest to try scare everybody with Thunberg scenarios that may have nothing to do with reality.  Neither you or I or anybody have absolute knowledge.  Watch Jacob Bronowski's Knowledge or Certainty.  We need to be humble about what we claim to know, especially when you are making rules which control the behavior of others.
author: John Stodalka

text: ¬†@John Stodalka¬† John:  You should avoid whatever web sites you are getting this climate "info" from.  You will not be OK with a +4¬∫C global rise in temperatures.  The last time temperatures rose +6¬∫C (252 million years ago), 90% of life on Earth perished.  Scientists do understand what caused the ice ages (small changes in Earth's orbit called Milankovich Cycles).  When there was 1.5 miles above where you are, CO2 levels were ~100 ppm less than the pre-industrial level.  Now they are 130 ppm higher and going up at 3 ppm/year!  Whether you are concerned about the climate emergency or not, that won't change what is happening.  It's real, It's us. It's bad.  We can do something about it and it will actually make the economy better compared to not doing anything.  We shouldn't put our heads in the sand.
author: Dan Miller

text:
¬†@Dan Miller¬† Hi Dan.  I am not a geologist.  I only became interested in the global warming/climate change/climate emergency issue 4 or 5 years ago because it completely took over the public conversation.  But from the little bit of reading I have done, what I have found particularly persuasive is that ocean levels rose 400 feet and 1.5 miles of ice melted in the past 18,000 years and obviously it had nothing to do with mankind's activity.  Let's bring that into the conversation when discussing climate change.  I don't think people are aware of these basic geological theories.    (These theories are not from a "website" by the way.  I don't think they are really disputed) .  My experience has been when people are told how the climate has so drastically changed in the past 18,000 years, obviously without any connection to human activity - well it puts things into perspective, doesn't it?    (My friends and family, not uneducated people, are also shocked to find out that CO2 is roughly .04% of the atmosphere, which isn't a very scary number at all.  It is really surprising how under informed people are about the debate about climate given the pervasiveness of the issue)

The climate alarmists scare me.  They are so certain of everything, even though so many of their predictions going back to James Hansen in 1988 have been ridiculously wrong.  


I really encourage you to watch Bronowski's Knowledge or Certainty from his Ascent of Man series for the BBC from 1973.  It was influential in my education.    You can find it on YouTube.

Doubt and humility are a good thing - it is not "sticking your head in the sand."  A latin phrase I love is de omnibus dubitandum - be suspicious of everything.  There is a totalitarian color to the climate movement which is absolutely terrifying.
author: John Stodalka

text: Fee and Dividend is not  replacement for other necessary action, it is part of a package of steps we must take to address climate change.  Aligning financial incentives with climate realities is a key part of any plan of action.
author: Dan Miller

text: The CO2 in (plants die, etc.) and out (photosynthesis, etc.) of the atmosphere is well balanced so while individual CO2 molecules enter and leave the atmosphere, the total amount of CO2 in the atmosphere is steady.  When we add excess CO2 to the atmosphere, that excess lasts for hundreds to thousands of years.

text:
I am not a climate change denier. I am a climate change realist because I believe that :- 
1. Climate is changing and has always changed
2. People who want to save the planet know that the planet having been ripped apart tectonically and put back together is in no need of saving, it has been around for 140,000,000,000 years and will be around long after we have left it (for other worlds hopefully). What they really mean is that they would like to stop it changing because they selfishly want to leave it how it is now because it is human friendly and they want to force it to stay that way but to disguise their selfishness to make it sound selfless and more heroic.
3. We are in a long glacial cycle iceage but the earth is warming because we are in an interglacial break... The earth,long term, is normally far cooler that this current period and that once this respite ends the normal cooling of the Earth will return killing off all life that can‚Äôt adapt. Remember we are 20 times more likely to die of cold than heat. We have had 5 ice ages that were near extinction events already.
4. Co2 has only a mild and short term effect as a greenhouse gas and it‚Äôs already absorbed and radiated as much heat as it can by the time we reached 200ppm in the atmosphere.

Radiative forcing or climate forcing is the difference between insolation (sunlight) absorbed by the Earth and energy radiated back to space. Changes to Earth's radiative equilibrium, that cause temperatures to rise or fall over decadal periods, are called climate forcings.

It is a property of co2 that it is able to absorb radiation only in the 14-16 micrometer band of back radiation. This range has been exhausted by the time we reached a co2 level of 200ppm. The latest NASA spectrum readings show that there is no free energy in that band left to be used by co2, it has all been absorbed and used. Therefore any extra co2 introduced into the environment can not increase back radiation and hence warming because the remaining warming is outside the radiation band it can absorb. Kind of like trying to make a red wall redder by laying more paint on it.

Increase in global temperatures is therefore not proof of increased back radiation of co2. Another reason for warming must exist and there are many many other reasons this may be occurring. 
Most of the models used by the IPCC are biased on co2 and assume it is the culprit despite being continually wrong for 40 years and use double or more the actual increases of co2 emissions currently being delivered. As I have said in another post - the proof of a model is it‚Äôs predictions and theirs are totally worthless despite billions spent on them annually. Money we could be spending on poverty and medical/scientific research for combating real problems like pollution and improving living conditions for all humanity.

text: I have nothing against solar or wind-if people want them fine-let the market be the market. I'm just saying you can't get to 100% energy production with these. Their scope is to supplement the grid so that when the grid is stressed such as in a time of war, a terrorism attack, an earthquake, a huge hurricane or blizzard, there are sources of energy to go to so that the most important aspects of society can function during the event.  Things like surgeries, evacuations, getting food etc to people stranded or in shelters, rescue equipment, refrigeration of foods, liquiids, medicines.  I.e. the minimal parts needed to run society.  What people don't understand-even the politicians is that removing oil heat as a heating source still means one is dependent on the electrical grid to provide heat.  What does electricity run on?  Nat gas, coal, water power.  Solar & wind at the moment do not store.
author: Kim Libera

text: Instead of all players competing for Congress' attention, it's best to let all players come to the market on energy production, vehicle type, home heating, etc.  Congress picks winners & losers because they are thinking of votes & donations from the non-profits, or campaign donations from the energy sector, farm subsidies, ethanol industry, motor vehicle industry etc.  They fail to understand how an energy grid works.  You can't get to 100% renewables. You may get to 30% & that would be considered excellent. It will vary in terms of proximity to source of manufacture & some physical conditions. But it does not control the weather-aka a Chevy Volt has no role in producing a hurricane or a Nor'easter.  What does matter to the owner of such is how much time will have to be allocated for recharging that battery & at what cost on the electric bill. Furthermore, when the family goes on vacation.  How do they plan their stops for a cross country trip ensuring they are always reaching a pitstop that can READILY charge their car w/o having to wait 8 hours in line to hook up.

text: Replay back to the early 2000s & my STS class-topic carbon trading markets. Slippery slope event-the curse of the worse night scenario: Ok company X, a wealthy factory sets up in region Z.  Company X produces a lot of stuff while still maintaining a profit margin. It is willing to pay the carbon fine. The UN is giddy over all the money rolling in just from company X so they send it country Oshkosh which is very poor. Oshkosh is now able to field light bulbs.  The UN folks are so giddy they think they are going to win the Nobel Peace Prize. But the folks in region Z, the few that there are are not happy. See they have been keeping up with the literature but they see a lot of stuff coming out of that factory & they say hey I thought all this climate stuff was to shut these people down. But you these people are too poor to move & too poor to lobby so X continues on. Well the squawking gets a tad louder to call attention to the UN. You see the folks  in Z believing in all the lit really want the company to shut down. But the folks in the UN say if we shut them down, no money comes in for us to send to Oshkosh. O my what to do. We really want our Peace Prize. If we shut X down, the train stops & we can't help Oshkosh.  Now therein lies the tragedy of the commons.  One man's pollution is another's treasure. But somewhere along the way the conundrum came along.  It pays (oshkosh) to pollute but someone also pays the price.  Bottom line carbon markets are not sound economic policy because one always has to keep company X in business if Oshkosh is to survive.

text: Yes it was.  Wealthy people use far more CO2 than the average person and governments generate about 30% of the CO2 but don't get a dividend.  Therefore, most households (the bottom 70%) make more on the dividend than they pay in higher prices due to the fee (according the US Treasury).  The wealthy pay more but it only a small amount to them.  And note that it is not necessary for people to spend their dividends on clean energy for the policy to work.  The purpose of the policy is to raise the cost of fossil fuels so that the price of fossil fuels more closely reflects its true cost to society.  This will make clean energy alternatives more competitive.

text:
Just one little thing wrong with your theory, besides the fact that it's looney-tunes pie-in-the-sky: you're going to take more money from me with every transaction, and give it back at the end of the month, and that's going to motivate/enable me to buy an electric vehicle no one makes yet, burn biogas and clean electricity my utilities don't provide, and put solar panels on the roof? 


TARIFFS ARE PAID BY THE CONSUMERS IN THE IMPORTING COUNTRY, NOT THE EXPORTERS; they just raise their prices to compensate. Donald Trump doesn't get that; neither does Dan Miller. There is absolutely no motivation for the fossil fuel companies to provide clean energy in a carbon tax; they will simply pass all of the tax on to us. There is no money in it to lend to clean-energy start-ups to bring their tech on line. It won't do a thing. It's a shell game, a con like trickle-down economics.


As for the carbon-tax schemes currently before congress, Deutch-Rooney and Baker-Schultz, both are scams--BS is worse--the main intent of which is to give the fossil fuel companies a get-out-of-jail-free card, a way to get out of paying taxes on fossil fuels they export OR import, and license to run amok for another ten years.


I make that seven little things wrong with your scheme.


I've been writing about the technologies that could get us out of this noose. There are a bunch of them: 88 pages worth, so far. They will eventually make our lives healthier, cleaner, and less expensive, but at first we need to make the conscious decision to invest in them, the most bang for the buck first, and to disinvest in the fossil fuel monsters, no matter that they want to call that socialism. The "free" (it isn't) market got us into this mess. Slavish worshipful mindless devotion to it will only get your grandchildren dead in misery.


If you want to carbon tax me, end all direct and indirect subsidies to the fossils first; stop all exports of gas oil coal; stop building coal and gas plants and require carbon capture and storage on those still in use. And DON'T rebate all of the money--Bill Gates won't miss it--but invest much of it in energy efficiency and new clean technologies. Or I will consider it tyranny--and intolerable stupidity--and resist accordingly.

author: Dan Miller

text:
1.  Yes, we are carbon-based life forms and plants need CO2... good so far.
2.  There is not a CO2 "drought".  All the life you see on Earth developed while CO2 was between 280 and 415 parts per million.
3.  Life did fine during the Ice Age when CO2 was about 180 ppm.
4.  Humans have increased atmospheric CO2 levels by about 40% (from 280 to 415 ppm).  We haven't doubled it yet.  The +1¬∫C warming so far came from that ~135 ppm increase but more warming is in the pipeline from the current elevated CO2.
5.  A doubling of CO2 (to 560 ppm) would increase temperatures by additional 2 to 4¬∫C in the short run and more later.  Recent studies show that a doubling in a warming world leads to more warming than previously thought (hence the 4¬∫C additional warming possibility).
6.  The CO2 that makes plants grow generally goes back to the atmosphere when the plant dies and decomposes.
7.  We are currently #2 in annual CO2 emissions and #1 in total emissions.
8.  Farm yields are being hurt by drought, floods, and heat. Those are much bigger effects than CO2 "greening".  Just ask a farmer!
author: Dan Miller

text: Yes, growing plants take CO2 out of the atmosphere and dying plants put it back.  The "carbon cycle" has many components but it used to be in balance until humans started burning fossil fuels and putting (now) about 40 gigatons of CO2 into the atmosphere every year.  While there is some extra "greening" due to the extra CO2, it is not nearly enough to offset human-derived CO2 and the other excess-CO2-caused changes to the carbon cycle, like more water vapor (another greenhouse gas) in the atmosphere because of the elevated temperature caused by the excess CO2.
author: Dan Miller

text:
¬†@Dan Miller¬† Of course it is more complicated.  But like all types of life plants grow well and reproduce more in favorable conditions and the plant population expands until it reaches an equilibrium where plants become population limited by a limit or limits on how much water, CO2, and sunlight to which they have access.  And, when a plant dies, it doesn't magically release all its carbon back into the atmosphere.  They die, fall, rot, and form a carbon rich layer of top soil.  New plants do not take in carbon from the soil, they get it from the CO2 in the air.

The so called climate scientists are the people looking for a simple answer to which most people will gravitate.  The reality is that everything is related and there are so many different types of interactions that understanding the earth's climate exceeds human capability to understand it much less predict future climate.
author: Jeffrey Johnson

text: ¬†@Jeffrey Johnson¬† So you think you know science well enough to say (simplistically) that excess CO2 doesn't remain in the atmosphere for a long time because of plants (ignoring that plants don't grow well in hotter, dryer climates) but for some reason actual climate scientists (dealing with many more variables than you do) don't know what they are doing?  Strange.  It also ignores the direct measurements we have of atmospheric CO2 steadily increasing since we started measuring it in 1958 (it went up 3 ppm in the past 12 months alone) which invalidates your hypothesis.
author: Dan Miller

text: ¬†@Dan Miller¬† So you think by quoting a couple numbers from junk scientists that makes you an expert?  You also completely ignore all the other factors that affect climate and the facts that there is very little correlation between CO2 levels, temperatures, sea levels, droughts, extreme weather, and the flourishing of animal snd plant life on earth and you ignore the fact that climate scientists have failed in every one of their predictions for many decades.
author: Jeffrey Johnson

text: ¬†@Jeffrey Johnson¬† ‚ÄúThe good thing about science is that it‚Äôs true whether or not you believe in it.‚Äù - Neil deGrasse Tyson
author: Dan Miller

text:
¬†@Dan Miller¬† I very much believe in science but I am intelligent nough not to trust very many scientists.  It's not that they set out to do poor quality work it's just that they report to people who control purse strings and budgets and are often to timid to challenge those authority figures.

Having worked in the field of aircraft control systems for many years, I've come to trust almost no managers who do not have degrees in technical fields and to trust very few that do.

If you dig into climate science just a bit (maybe a few hundred hours depending on your background knowledge before starting), you'll come to realize that there a few experts with very small areas of expertise that are  basically working alone or in small groups to paint a few pixels of the photograph and the people who are arranging the pixels into a climate change picture are politicians with no technical backgrounds.  They basically paint the picture they want and write a narrative to go along with it.  Uunfirtunately for them, they aren't bright enough to craft a story that holds up to any scrutiny.
author: Jeffrey Johnson

text: ¬†@Jeffrey Johnson¬† Science (not just climate science) is based on skepticism.  The peer review process filters out non rigorous science.  The process works for the most part in medicine, astronomy, and many other fields including climate.  It's just not true that climate scientists have over predicted the speed and intensity of climate impacts.  If anything, they have been too conservative.  There are objective measures that tell us that climate change is well underway.  For example, the Earth has warmed about +1¬∫C since the industrial revolution; the volume of summer Arctic sea ice has dropped 70% in the past 30 years; sea level rise is accelerating; "Extremely Hot Summers" (an average summer temperature more than 3 standard deviations above the 1951-1980 mean) have increased over 5000% (50 times) in the past 50 years.  All of these things are just measurements... they are not predictions and are not based on models... they already happened.  And the science tells us why they happened.  You can dismiss it, but it doesn't change that it is true.  If you have alternative theories, you should write them up and submit them to a peer review journal.
author: Dan Miller

text:
¬†@Dan Miller¬† ¬†Dan Miller¬† Peer review requires that you present your hypothesis, your calculations/models, your experiments, your raw data, your assessment of how your data and/or experiments support your hypothesis, and accept skeptical feedback.  The majority of these steps are missing in the climate alarm hypotheses, so there has not been any fair peer review.

Those people who have challenged various climate change hypotheses have been routinely smeer atacked, have had their funding pullled by way of political pressure, and have been forced out of their research jobs at universities.

As for the things you claim are just facts based on measurements, they are just cherry picked data for specific time periods from particular data sets.

A 1¬∞C rise in temperature since the industrial age?  Over what exact time period?  Is this a change in the average global temperature or in a particular region?  Are the start and end average temperatures a 30 year moving average or are they just average temperatures for a single year?  How did the the set of temperature sensors change over the period of measurement?  Certainly, in the preindustrial period, these measurements were made by individuals reading thermometers, so how often each day were readings taken and recorded?  The sad truth is that even today, if we just use ground based sensor data, we cannot get an accurate global temperature simply because we do not have enough sensors in many regions of the world and especially the oceans and if we cannot do it now with all our technological advancements, we certainly could not do it in the preindustrial age.  The only fair way to compare that age with our current time would be to only use temperature measurement locations that existed in the preindustrialized time and that still have sensors at the same locations as we do today, then eliminate all locations from both data sets where the location is in a current (or past) heat island, and only use data that was collected at the same Greenwich mean times.  Of course you still have to try to be fair about the start and ending dates to avoid starting or ending on particularly cold or warm years.  Or, rather than drawing a simple trend line, you can graph the results for each year or each season and let everyone see the actual variations from year to year.  This still won't tell us about the actual average global temperature, but it is at least somewhat fair in that it would be a comparison between equivalent data sets.

As for polar ice, the ice in the Antarctic has been growing for many years and the ice in Greenland has also been growing.  Sea ice is moved around by ocean currents and winds and it's melt rate is affected by ocean temperatures and flow rates, air temperatures and winds, and solar radiance.  How much ice is in the sea is also affected by how much land ice calves off and calving can be increased by warm temperatures but can also be increased by increases in the flow of ice caused by additional snow piling up on land and increasing the pressure on the ice sheet.

Climate alarmists love to take a bit of cherry picked data, predict doom and gloom, scream that we face a terrible problem if we don't fund their research to find a solution to their made up problem, and then fund corporations and/or governments to implement their proposed solution.  That is their gig and they are very good at selling their snake oil.
author: Jeffrey Johnson

text: ¬†@Jeffrey Johnson¬† Of course the peer review process for climate change includes the items you listed. If you are interested in the nitty gritty of how the global average temperature was and is calculated you can look up the scientific papers that describe that.  Have fun!  Antarctic land ice has been shrinking, not growing, as shown by the Grace gravity satellites.  Look it up (check out SkepticalScience.com).  I'm sorry that you believe in climate conspiracy theories.  They're not true.

author: jose carlos

text: An excellent talk, but there are two flaws in the tax & dividend solution he proposes.  First, it assumes that people won't simply use the dividend to pay the higher price for fossil fuels and products, which would mean that fossil fuel production would not be reduced significantly and CO2 emissions would continue to add to the current CO2 levels.  The second flaw is that it does nothing to reduce the current CO2 levels of 400+ ppm down to the historic levels (180-280 ppm).   His solution thus might slow the accumulation of CO2, but doesn't solve the problem.  Instead of a dividend, we should require fossil fuel extractors to recapture the carbon they extract or import every year.  This could be done in gradual increments as he proposes, up to recapturing 110% until CO2 levels fall below 280 ppm, at which point they would only have to recapture 100%.  This is not a tax, but makes the mitigation of pollution a cost of fossil fuel production.  It is really no different than regulations on other types of pollution.  It is a free market approach that allows companies to pick their own method of recapturing carbon.

text: Believe it or not, oil companies including ExxonMobil support Fee and Dividend!  There is a conservative group called Climate Leadership Council that supports a version of F&D that is a bit watered down, but is essentially the same as what I describe in my talk.  The oil companies want the carbon fee to be coupled with reductions in other environmental regulations and elimination of their liability for past emissions.  The oil companies know that a carbon price is coming and would rather have a known-in-advance, steadily rising fee than one that is volatile.  That's not only good for them, but its also good for investors in clean energy alternatives.
author: Dan Miller

text: Yes, many governments use fossil fuel taxes to pay for government programs.  But the Fee and Dividend fee will keep growing every year (with all the money going directly to the public).  Since there are clean alternatives to fossil fuels (some of which are already cheaper than fossil fuels), eventually, almost all clean alternatives will be far cheaper so people will choose them over fossil fuels and fossil fuel emissions will drop.

But we know that manmade global warming is increasing the likelihood of near-term mega-droughts in the southwest US and other places (like the Mediterranean).
author: Dan Miller

text:
¬†@Dan Miller¬† My issue is that so many are blaming anything and everything on global warming, when the same things can, and have, happened purely naturally.


The 1900s was an unusually wet century. We didn't really know any better. But they did all their planning assuming that it was California's natural state when it wasn't. So when it reverts to a more stable and natural condition, they don't have enough water. If they would just say that global warming is contributing to it, fine, but they won't own up to the mistakes they made in the past.
author: Diane Merriam

text:
¬†@Diane Merriam¬† There were wildfires before humans walked the Earth but that does not mean that humans can't cause wildfires or that we can't know if they do.  There were droughts and wet periods in the past but the changes that are happening now because of our burning of fossil fuels are dramatic and far more consequential that the changes we saw in the past 1000 years.  For example, humans have increased the CO2 concentration in the atmosphere by about 130 ppm in the past 150 years (from 280 ppm in late 1800's to 410 ppm now). During the ice age, CO2 was ~100 ppm less than the 1800's and there was 2 miles of ice above Boston.  The last time (a long time ago) CO2 was TODAY'S value (410 ppm), sea levels were about 75 feet higher than today (it will take a while for that much ice to melt, but that's where we're heading).  We are heading to a completely different climate than the one that civilization developed under... not just a bit wetter or dryer than now.  

The climate has changed before for natural reasons (over tens of thousands of years, not 150) and 252 million years ago, the temperature increased by +6¬∫C... and 90% of life on Earth perished.  That is the level of warming we will see next century on the path we are on (and we could see +4¬∫C this century).

I could also go on about how we know the excess CO2 in the atmosphere comes from the burning of fossil fuels (using carbon dating) and other ways we know these changes are caused by humans, but that's another TEDx talk.
author: Dan Miller

text:
¬†@Dan Miller¬† Again. What bugs me is those who say that weather or weather-related events are 100% totally and completely caused by CO2. Yes, we have put more CO2 into the atmosphere than would be there naturally. Yes, more CO2 does increase the temperature and makes events that are affected by higher temperatures more probable.


The 97% consensus, and I'd expect a larger percentage than that, is on the basic science of greenhouse gases. For each doubling of the CO2 concentration in the atmosphere, the temperature will go up about 1.1C. So purely from CO2, the temperature would only go up by 1.1 C when it gets to 540 ppm. I kind of doubt we'll hit that, but we surely won't hit another doubling, up to 1080 ppm. 


I'm not sure about the catastrophic predictions. They're using very high numbers for sensitivity multipliers that just don't make sense or that are based on guesses, not science. There is nowhere near consensus on the sensitivity numbers. That's a completely separate theory and one that hasn't held up well. 


CO2, in and of itself, is a fairly weak greenhouse gas. They're using primarily water vapor for the rest of it. The problem is, we can't model clouds worth beans. Different kinds of clouds, different altitudes, different times, different places. The models are extremely simplistic, and even the IPCC admits that, if you dig into the actual report and not just the summary that's put out for media and politicians.


Their models were trained on the known (well, known but then adjusted to what they think they ought to be) temperatures between about 1950 and 2000. But you can make an equation that exactly matches any data set if you use enough terms. The validation is when the model consistently matches data outside the training period. And they don't. The further you go before 1950 and after 2000, the less the models track the reality. Of course, now they're training them with more years after 2000, but they still don't match the pre-1950 years. If they can't accurately hindcast, then they can't accurately forecast.


On large time scales, you've got plate tectonics. For example, North and South America haven't been joined for that long, geologically speaking. Prior to that, there was a current between them that ran directly between the Pacific and Atlantic. Major climate shift when the Ring of Fire volcanos closed that off. 



The major changes going every 25,000 years or so at a time have nothing to do with CO2. They are caused by orbital mechanics. How circular the orbit is. How much the spin axis is slanted. Which hemisphere is closest to the sun at perihelion. Look up Milankovich cycles.

There was a huge and incredibly fast shift, both down and then up, about 12,000 years ago. Look up the Younger Dryas period for details, but we're talking degrees per decade, or even years. There are two conflicting theories on its cause right now. It was either a meteor crash (like the dino killer, but not quite so big), or a huge, fresh water inland sea in North America that had been held back by an ice dam which catastrophically broke.
author: Diane Merriam

text:
¬†@Diane Merriam¬† No one says that a particular weather event is 100% caused by climate change, but we can say that certain events were likely caused by climate change (and, conversely, were likely not natural events).  For example, Extremely Hot Summers (defined as an average summer temperature for a particular place that is 3 or more standard deviations (3+ sigma) more than the 1951-1980 baseline mean) are now happening 50 times (5000%) more often than 50 years ago.  So, when an Extremely Hot Summer happens today, we can say that there is a 49 out of 50 (98%) chance that it was caused by global warming.  Note that this is not based on models or predictions... it already happened and we know it by simply reading thermometers.

A doubling of CO2 was generally expected to raise temperatures by +3¬∫C when all "short-term" effects are included.  Recent research, that takes new knowledge of clouds into account, suggests that the doubling temperature may be closer to 5¬∫C.  And when longer-term feedbacks (e.g., permafrost melt, Arctic methane release, etc.) the temperature rise will be even more.  Yes, there is uncertainty in this estimate (as there is in ALL science), and that is not reason for inaction, it is reason for action!  Uncertainty is not your friend.  If there was a 25% chance that a plane would crash, would you put your child on it?  Of course not.  Scientists are pretty sure that the world will warm by +3¬∫C or more this century on the path we are on and they are also pretty sure that will lead to catastrophe.  Is there uncertainty?  Yes.  Is there a small chance they are wrong?  Yes.  Does that mean we should use our "optimism bias" to continue on our merry way?  No!

Yes, the climate has changed before because of natural causes.  But when you say this your are implying (1) humans aren't causing the current warming, and/or (2) the warming won't harm us.  Both of those implications are false.
author: Dan Miller

text:
¬†@Dan Miller¬† We can say that a particular event has been exacerbated by global warming, but not that it is caused by it.


When you can accurately hindcast and explain the 20s to 40s and especially the 30s, where far more high temperatures (not the highest temperatures, but the most days when a new high was created) were recorded and the temperature trend was almost exactly the same as the 70s to 2000s in both rate of increase and how long the increase went on, then we can talk. Yet I have never, not ever, gotten any more from anyone than "it was natural," with no proof, and no explanation. The 30s and 40s were also the record highs of those days. Yet we didn't start putting enough CO2 into the atmosphere to matter until well into the 50s.


You're doing the same thing here. Stating something doesn't prove anything, no matter how many times it's said. "We know," or They know," doesn't explain anything. No, 3 C per doubling is not a given. 5 C is even less of a given.


The "choices" being given are now along the line of "We're going to intentionally crash that plane 5 minutes after take-off to try and prevent a worse crash if it should happen to crash from 30,000 ft for any other reason." 


Yes. We've caused a certain amount of warming. Yes, there will be a price to pay. No, without actual science, I'm not going to assume an unmanageable catastrophe. Until I can see anyone actually accurately modeling clouds, until I can see anyone accurately explaining the past, until I can see anyone making economic comparisons between what they are demanding vs what amelioration would cost, then I can't back it.


There's not much point in continuing a discussion where there is no discussion.
author: Diane Merriam

text:
¬†@Diane Merriam¬† The 1930's were warm in the US but only a couple of years make the Top 10 warmest US years.  And the contiguous US is only 1.56% of the surface area of the Earth so a warm US is just a local phenomenon.  Globally, the 1930s and 1940s were much cooler than today. 

Science is ALWAYS uncertain.  There is no such things as proof in science (but there is in mathematics).  If you are waiting for proof or certainty, we are in a lot of trouble.

And as I pointed out before, you don't need models or predictions to know things are changing rapidly and not for the better.  I mentioned Extremely Hot Summers already.  Here's another:  The volume of summer Arctic sea ice has dropped 70% in just the past 30 years and is expected to drop to zero (in summer) for the first time in human history in about a decade.  A dark blue Arctic sea instead of a bright, reflecting cover of ice will greatly warm the top of the Earth and make even more dramatic changes to the Jet Stream.  These things are not good and are not models or predictions (except for the near-term demise of the Arctic sea ice, which is a sure thing at this point).

If you watched my talk, you saw that we can start to address climate change while creating million of jobs and growing GDP by $1.4 trillion.  Why not do that?  Why take the chance that we are putting our children on that doomed plane?  You are arguing that changing may cost more than the benefits the change provides.  But it is clear that staying on the path we are on is clearly the most expensive and disruptive plan.
author: Dan Miller

text:
¬†@Dan Miller¬† None of the 1930s are any longer in the top ten as to highest temperature. What they do still lead at is the number of record highs set. It was heat that set in and didn't break for weeks or even months at a time. And of course, the thirty's were cooler than today. But they were a lot warmer, even worldwide, than the temperatures in the 1900s and 1910s. And by about the same amount as we are warmer than the 1970s. And this is before we were putting enough CO2 into the atmosphere to make any difference.


I'm not trying to say that global warming isn't real or that our CO2 emissions have warmed the Earth more than it would be without us. That would be denying science. CO2 is a greenhouse gas. The more CO2, the warmer it gets. The question is the multiplier. 


That multiplier isn't based on science. It's based on computer models. On what-ifing. On training a huge equation on recorded data and then expecting the projection to match reality. If no one can do that to the stock market (and hundreds, if not thousands have tried), a much simpler system than the climate of a planet, then I have little faith in their models. When those models cannot accurately hindcast data that it hasn't been trained on, I have even less. When scientists can explain the Little Ice Age, both its inception and its end, I might believe more. When scientists can explain the previous peaks of warming, of which I know of at least four (Holocene Maximum, Minoan, Roman, and Medieval), their inceptions and ends, I might believe more. But they can't.


You cannot create jobs simply by saying so. The money to pay for any climate change workers is less money available to pay other workers in actual productive jobs. 


The emphasis on wind and solar to the exclusion of any other source is not good. Not by any means. You cannot run an industrial economy without stable electricity 24/7. There is no inexpensive way of storing enough intermittent energy at the scale needed even on paper in other than a few specific places that have the useful geographical features needed. Poorer countries would suffer even more. They can't even build a modern economy at the dual cost of solar/wind and complete backup power. That means leaving hundreds of millions to their suffering and likely bring even more back down into extreme poverty. They need cheap and plentiful power.


There's a pattern I see all too often in both fearful and "true believers" people. "We must do something. This is something. We must do this." 


The only source I can see for generating power of the kind needed for a modern society that is "green" is nuclear. But people have an emotional fear, created by the environmentalists of the 60s and 70s, that a nuclear plant is a bomb waiting to happen. Except it isn't and hasn't. 


More people have died installing solar panels than have died from radiation exposure in nuclear power plants (and no, I don't count the two bombs). That includes Chernobyl (unknown exactly, but estimated at less than 200, including those who get and die from thyroid cancer), Three Mile Island (0), and Fukushima (1). Chernobyl was built without even a containment dome. TMI vented a tiny bit, but almost all of it was contained, as designed, inside. Fukushima killed about 1600 people. Not from the plant itself, but in the panic to get away from it. One death has been officially accepted as a direct result of radiation exposure. Fukushima today has less radiation around it than many highly populated places have naturally with no adverse health effects.


There are new reactor designs on the table today that would be far, far safer than anything currently running. China is building a few interesting ones. But the best one seems to be the molten salt Thorium reactors. Unfortunately, the US government has an incredibly antiquated procedure for building even test reactors on anything with a scale over what fits in a lab. Needless to say, that just won't work.


To sum it up, I place little confidence in the computer models, for the reasons listed. I think the push for solar and wind is counterproductive in the long run and, even in many places the short term. I am an engineer who created my own "energy" engineering degree way back when no one offered one by doing a dual concurrent major in electrical and mechanical engineering.  My first scientific love was actually nuclear physics. But I wasn't thrilled with the nuclear plant designs of the day.


I love the idea of solar and wind *where it makes sense*. Places with no easy connection to a power grid and that don't need a lot of power. People's homes or office buildings in high power cost places where solar or wind on a small scale, that is available consistently, can be economically competitive as long as they still have the grid to fall back on when needed. As an engineering way of thinking, I need actual proof with actual numbers before I believe things and I need practical methods for dealing with them.
author: Diane Merriam

text: Not true... the purpose of the policy is to make the cost of fossil fuels reflect their true cost to society.  By making fossil fuels cost more, that makes clean energy more competitive and, therefore, everyone ends up using more clean energy.  The purpose of the dividend is to make the public support a high price on carbon.  If the public spends their dividends on clean energy and products, that's great but it is not necessary for the policy to do its job... moving us to a clean energy economy.
author: Dan Miller

text:
¬†@Dan Miller¬† I agree in principle, but I think my proposal would do more to counteract the influence of human nature.


In the West, at least, the % of renewable energy generate is increasing rapidly and its price is plummeting as a result, already making it an attractive option for economic reasons. Obviously, this varies from country-to-country depending on their potential to generate renewable energy (enough wind?), their wealth, the influence of fossil fuel companies, and political will. For instance, Australia's solar power potential is vast, capable of not only supplying its domestic needs, but has the potential to sell surpluses to its neighbours to the north. This is being stifled by right-wing politicians determined to keep using their large coal reserves. Their majority in parliament is very slim, and the power of environmental parties is increasing.


In New Zealand (where I live), a large % of consumers cannot afford to purchase EVs and green appliances due to their price, even if they are aware of the long-term socio-economic benefits. At this stage, only the upper-middle and upper class can afford to purchase a brand new EV. A newly-introduced gov't scheme penalizing ICE vehicles by increasing their price, while subsidizing the cost of EVs will help, I would also like to see legal restrictions phased in, which would only allow hybrids and/or the most fuel-efficient ICEs to be purchased or to continue to be driven.
Polls show that a large increase in the sales of EVs would occur if the price was more competitive (I think a recent poll put it around 90%). Sales are increasingly slowly, but the GHG reduction is tiny. When there was last a large spike in the cost of oil, EV sales skyrocketed, but went back to their pitiful numbers once the price fell. A sustained, global oil crisis is perhaps the best single solution to ridding ourselves of most ICEs. 


Receiving a regular dividend from the gov't that can only be invested in green products/services would allow a lot of people to make the switch from an ICE to an EV. The same goes for appliances like fridges, washing machines, dishwashers, insulation, double-glazing, etc. There was a subsidy here, which has since expired, unfortunately, subsidizing the cost of installing solar panels on houses that was successful. It would be far more effective now, if reintroduced, because the efficiency of solar has increased significantly, while the capital cost has decreased a great deal.  


History has shown that the public cannot be relied upon to spend their money on products and services that are both good for them and their family, and society as a whole. This includes tax cuts or gov't handouts. How many people would spend their cash dividends on long-haul flights for a vacation instead of upgrading to a green appliance? Limiting their options is, by far, the best course of action.
author: markrm16

text: ¬†@markrm16¬† As I said, the purpose of the policy is to increase the price of fossil fuels.  People can spend the dividend the way they want (for example, a                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  poor person who needs to spend more money on heating their apartment can use the dividend to buy food).  It will be a good thing to implement other polices as well, such as banning ICE cars by a certain date.  But we should keep the F&D policy clean.

text:
It would be nice if this were true... but it is not.  Deforestation adds to climate change and reforestation will help somewhat if we did it, but the majority of the excess CO2 in the atmosphere comes from digging up fossil fuels and burning them.  The Sun was at a century-low recently while global warming was accelerating, so a cooling Sun won't help us. And forget models, thermometers tell us the Earth has warmed about +1¬∫C since the industrial revolution.  Thermometers (and some math) show us that Extremely Hot Summers (an average summer temperature for a particular place that is more than 3 standard deviations above the 1951-1980 mean) have already increased over 5000% (50 times) in the past 50 years.  That is not a prediction and is not based on a model... it already happened (and is getting worse).

Also, not breathing out won't help.  The carbon that we breathe out comes from the food we eat which in turns comes from the CO2 in the atmosphere, so our breathing is carbon neutral!

text:
"we can stop global warming by taxing it". That has to be the most bizarre solution ever.
If this gentleman did his homework, he would realise several obvious flaws in his theory. First of all, if you tax (which he calls fee) the oil producing industries, they will automatically pass that onto the consumer. Which means higher fuel costs. The tax receipts will only pay for the higher price, not the green cars. Secondly, who is to say that everyone will just spend their extra income on jusr cars, they might increase consumption on all commodities, not just one. In fact, the latter is a far more probable outcome.

There is a huge amount of tax on fuel already. Think about the time when fuel cost was only a few cents per litre. Fuel is a highly inelastic good, that is why it is so heavily taxed. All the tax goes into the pockets of the government and oil producing industries. So the idea that the consumer will benifits is a fantasy.

The best way to tackle fuel costs and the environmental impact of greenhouse emissions is not by yet another raid of the pockets of the consumer, its by investing on new technology. We already have a technology that could offset the use of cars, its called trains. They are powered by electricity and they carry a lot of people around which makes them very efficient. Of course wind and solar power are more harmful to the environment than fossil fuel. They require large swathes of wild land to be farmed, destroying wild life habitat and not even providing enough power to meet demand. So we would need to continue using fossil fuel to top up supply. Nuclear power would cut greenhouse emissions immediately, and by supplying the rail industry with such source of electricity we can cut the cost of travelling by rail, and people would automatically switch. High fuel costs already discourage people from using cars. The state only needs to provide an alternative. That is in fact the problem. There is no alternative at the moment.

Trains can go under ground, leaving the surface for people and animals. They use up a fraction of surface space compared to roads. They carry several carriages, making economy of scale an option during peak hours. They run on electricity, which if produced from nuclear power, cuts greenhouse emissions by a significant amount due to the fact that it needs no top up from other sources.

One thing that will definitely not work, is yet more tax on fuel. People use fuel because they have to, its the only way to get to work.

text:
Unless you are very wealthy, the Fee and Dividend policy will make you money since you personally generate less than the average amount of CO2 per person.  Because wealthy people generate far more CO2 than the average person and governments generate about 30% of CO2 but don't get a dividend, it turns out that about 70% of households will make more money on the dividend than they pay in higher prices.

You're correct that planting trees and making machines to remove CO2 from the air are good things to do. But adding more CO2 to the atmosphere will not make the world a better place.  Many plants do grow more with more CO2, but there are other effects such are higher temperatures, more droughts and more floods, and more diseases that also impact living things and, on the whole, more CO2 is not good (if you care about living things that evolved in a world with 280 ppm of CO2).
author: Dan Miller

text: It's a fee and dividend. In current implementations, it's nowhere near high enough to be considered a UBI. The essential mechanism is to depress consumption of fossil fuels while compensating users for the amount that they typically emit, so consumers will economically be incentivised to choose lower-carbon activities.

author: Dan Miller

text:
You are correct that the fee will lead to increase prices for fossil fuels and things made by or with fossil fuels.  That's the purpose of the policy... to make the price of fossil fuels more closely match its true cost.  But individual poor people are not the largest consumer of goods because, um, they're poor.  Poor people fly less and use less fossil fuels, so their dividends  will almost always exceed the extra amounts they pay due to the fee (studies show that the bottom 70% of households will make money on an F&D policy).

I gave this talk in Orange County, which is a fairly conservative place.  I had traditional conservatives and libertarians come up to me afterwards and say they supported the policy.  There is a mainstream conservative group, The Climate Leadership Council, that supports F&D (they call it Carbon Dividends Plan).  Even ExxonMobile supports it!  If you think about it, F&D IS a conservative plan: (1) it uses market forces to address the problem, (2) it doesn't raise government revenues at all, and (3) it doesn't pick winners or losers.

Population is a big factor in emissions and we should take steps to address population growth.  One of the best ways to do that is to educate girls and woman around the world. But that's another TED talk.

text:
I don't think you understand the purpose of the fee/tax.  As you point out, fossil fuel companies will pass on the cost of the fee to users and that will raise the price of fossil fuels... that is the PURPOSE of the policy.  The idea is to make the price of fossil fuels reflect the costs they inflict on society (the cost beyond the purchase price that you, me, and everyone else must pay because of the damage that fossil fuels cause).  Higher priced fossil fuels will be less competitive with renewables, so renewables (and other low-carbon energy sources plus efficiency) will take over.  The point is to price fossil fuels out of the market.  The reason the money collected is given back to the public is to have them accept a high fee on fossil fuels.  If they spend it on EVs or insulating their home, that's great but it is not required for the policy to be effective.  They may buy more things because the policy improves the economy, but those new things will more and more be made with renewable energy.

Trains are great but transportation is only a portion of the emissions problem.  And replacing roads with (underground!) trains everywhere will take far more time than we have to address emissions.

text:
"FIX climate change"? First, the climate will never be static; it is always changing. Humans don't have the power and never will have the power to stop the climate from changing. The natural forces that change the climate are simply too powerful and too numerous. 
Second, the only change in the climate that is always dangerous to humans, history has proven, is sufficient global cooling to trigger ice age glaciation. That change threatens human food supplies and requires massive increases in energy to provide enough heat to maintain civilization. Even the small cooling of the Little Ice Age was devastating to human civilization. 
Warming, in contrast, has NOT historically been dangerous to humanity. We may not like moving away from lowland coastal areas, we may not like erecting barriers to flooding, and the like, but we will like the food abundance and lower energy needs that come with warming. Warming has always been bountiful to human civilization. 
So the claim that we need to "fix" climate change is specious. It is impossible, and change to more warmth is not a threat. 


What we really need to do, what the Global Warming Extremist Agenda PREVENTS us from doing, is preparing to endure the inevitable climate change to serious cooling. That is what should be worrying us. That is where we should be investing our research and resources.

text:
Excellent presentation. I have some similar ideas but these also attack our national debt and deficit as well as social security which are also on the path to a tipping point.
Here's an idea, lets impose an environmental impact tax on corporations based on emissions and environmental damage of their products or service. Eliminate all tax subsidies to all energy sources. Use the revenue generated by the environmental impact tax to fund Social Security and Medicare. Add long term care to Medicare. Prorate Social Security and Medicare for non-retired and those not currently on medicare based on the number of quarters contributed. Use peoples current SS & medicare their employers "contribution" to fund individual retirement and health care and term life insurance accounts not to be withdrawn until 59.5 years old except in the case of health care, disability, or death. Medicare will make up any medical shortfall for health, disability, or life insurance regardless of age. This approach would work very much like the benefits federal employees and retires are currently receiving but for the whole country and accomplish the following objectives objectives: 
1) Reduce or green house emissions and other environmental pollution as much as feasible and economically possible
2) Eliminate or greatly reduce the national deficit a debt
3) Provide capital investment to keep the economy growing. 
4) Redistribute wealth based on consumption, not income.
5) Relieve pressure on the Social Security and Medicare and provide seniors with retirement medical and financial security
6) Provide health care, disability, and life insurance open to all American citizens

author: Stormy Sampson

text:
Wrong.  The natural forces that change the climate (changes in the Sun's output, changes in the Earth's orbit, long-term release of CO2 from massive volcanoes or continental movements) are small over the past 150 years compared to the man-made changes increasing the CO2 content of the atmosphere from 280 ppm to 415 ppm (a 48% increase in the past 150 years!).  The only natural forcing that is more than a tiny amount in the past 150 years is changes in the Sun's output... it's about 10% of the man-made CO2 effect and the Sun has been cooler than average over the past decades!

And the world does fine with Ice Ages.  Humans got through the last one.  But big warmings are associated with mass extinction events like the one that happened 252 million years ago when it warmed +6¬∫C and about 90% of all life on Earth perished.  We are on track to warm +6¬∫C by next century.  We should probably get off that track.
