text:
Yes, the earth was warmer about 150 million years ago. You know what was also the case back then: far higher CO2 levels. All that carbon has - over the course of millions of years - been stored underground since then. The current ecosystem is in no way adapted to CO2 levels above 300ppm (because they oscillated between about 200-280ppm for the last couple of millions of years). Recently we crossed the 400ppm mark...

In recent geological history (read: a few million years) temperatures were never that high, and especially never rose that quickly. During the ice ages and interglacials the temperature changed by about 5¬∞C over a 100.000-year cycle. Currently we're at +2¬∞C in 150 years - spot the difference.
author: Stephan Weinberger

text: As I point out in the talk, CO2 remains in the atmosphere for hundreds to thousands of years, so global warming won't "reverse" by reducing fossil fuel use, etc. though it will slow down its advance.  To "reverse" global warming, we need to remove CO2 from the atmosphere using mechanical means (called Direct Air Capture) or by accelerating natural processes (for example, putting iron in the ocean to create algae blooms that can then sink to the bottom, taking carbon with it).
author: Dan Miller

text: But hydrogen does not exist on its own.  We usually derive it from natural gas and then release the resulting CO2 to the atmosphere!  It is possible to get hydrogen using renewable energy, but it more efficient (and less costly) to just use a battery.
author: Dan Miller

text: Plus: Water vapor is a greenhouse gas as well (even more than CO2).

text: And we know what caused the ice ages and we know what's causing the current warming (hint: it's not the same cause).

text:
@Janice Barket The ice-age cycle is about 100,000 years, with temperature changing by about 5¬∞C and CO2 fluctuating between ~200 and 280ppm over that timescale.

In the last 150 years we had almost +2C¬∞ and we recently crossed the 400ppm threshold - spot the difference.
author: Stephan Weinberger

text: Um, climate change is here now and the predictions have under predicted what has happened so far.  We have seen Extremely Hot Summers (3 sigma above the mean) before but they are now happening 50 times more often than just 50 years ago, so "seeing something before" does not mean the climate isn't changing.  The CO2 we are emitting was underground for ~100 million years and is not just being recycled from the atmosphere.  I don't know what you are trying to say about a "closed system" but a greenhouse effect is certainly happening on Earth since without it, the Earth would be a frozen snowball.  Real science is open to alternative theories.  What is your alternative theory?

text: Everything you said is simply not true.  Ice sheets are decreasing globally... the volume of summer Arctic sea ice has dropped 70% in the past 30 years!  Sea level rise is accelerating.  Winters are not colder on average (though they get cold in some places... after all it's winter!).  Summers are not cooler.  The number of Extremely Hot Summers (3+ sigma above the mean) has increased over 5000% in the past 50 years.  Facts do matter and you're not allowed to just make them up!
author: Dan Miller

text:
@Rick Kinsman This is a bit tricky: Yes, in some regions shelf ice sheets are growing in size. You know why that's happening? Because the inland ice sheets are melting and thereby diluting the saltwater of the surrounding oceans. Less salt content means that the water freezes at higher temperatures.

So yes, the area of shelf ice is growing in some places, but the volume of inland ice is rapidly shrinking.

text:
¬†@Dan Miller¬† Long post here, but jump to the end for my alternative ideas. At the first logic step of this program yes. A income distribution scheme would create a situation where lower income people would receive something. The problem is the reaction to this adjustment. A carbon tax will, almost by definition, create more expensive energy prices globally under the plan proposed in the video. If energy prices increase, then the standard of living/health of those on the extreme level of poverty goes down.
     Corporations are not going to make up this dividend, they will find ways out of this and the monies that are collected via this tax will be very vulnerable to centralized corruption and siphoning.¬†
     For example, the US collects tax revenue each year, that if less than 3% was earmarked for feeding children worldwide, would eliminate 100% of deaths from food insecurity. At the same time, huge sums are paid to farmers in subsidies to NOT grow crops on arable land (to artificially increase food prices in the markets). American women spend more on lipstick averaged annually than they do on immunizing and feeding starving children.¬†
    I applaud your motivation, and your idealism. But fundamentally if you want to change human carbon production, you have to do it directly, since indirect ways end up having too many adverse effects.¬†

    So what to do? 



Remove the carbon dioxide....
The US has over 32 million acres of land and rents many of the forests to loggers. If the US spent part of its military budget planting trees, they would sequester billions and billions of tons per decade. 
   Want to decrease emissions? Cut government use of carbon emitting services. Make all government buildings solar powered, transport government workers via electric busses, make all military bases run on renewables 100% 

The way that I know that a carbon tax will fail, is that the lawmakers are not willing to give up burning, consuming etc. They aren't willing to adopt migrant children, to ride-share, to ride a bike to the capital to live in tiny homes and go vegan. Its a classic case of "do as I say not as I do, and give me your money"
author: Update my Settings

text: ¬†@Update my Settings¬† Quick responses: (1) Poor people are helped by the policy (they make more on the dividend than they pay in higher prices); (2) Fossil fuel energy is MORE expensive when all real costs are included, so this policy will reduce total costs to society; (3) Unfortunately, while planting trees is a good thing, it doesn't permanently sequester CO2... when the trees die from fire, drought, bark beetle, etc., they will release their CO2 back to the atmosphere (at the worst possible time!); (4)  Other mandates such as requiring 100% carbon-free energy by a certain date, banning fossil fuel cars by a certain date, etc., are good things and are beginning to happen and are complimentary to Fee and Dividend.  If those mandates can be passed by governments, the carbon pricing policy can too.
author: Dan Miller

text:
¬†@Dan Miller¬† While I agree that there will be an initial redistribution that will help low income people, I generally think that the economic system will be too adaptive (businesses moving, political interests and lobbying, etc) for this plan to work long term. 
   On the tree based sequestration, there needs to be a mechanism to maintain these forests and also to remove and store the carbon and that is just a part. 
  If you wanted to start pulling large amounts of C02 out of the atmosphere, there are of course faster ways of doing this. Simply producing lime (calcium carbonate) can be used to draw out billions of tons in short order.¬†
        I can think of dozens of synergistic solutions if we want to drop CO2 concentrations. There is one single main thing that I strongly feel is the core of these solutions, and that is an abundant and cheap source of energy. My main point of contention, is that I do not think that manufacturing plastic/mined metal based solar panels and landscape diminating wind turbines, are very good solutions.¬†
There are only about 3x10^12 tons of the stuff in the atmosphere all together, and fusion based electrical generation can take a pretty chunk of that out if need be.¬†
      I will make you a deal. If you can get the representatives, senators and business owners behind carbon tax legislation to sell their large homes, walk to work, and turn down their thermostats to 55 in the DC winters. Then I will have a modicum of belief that they are deserving of using force to compel the rest of the country to do the same.
author: Update my Settings

Fusion will be great if and when it comes, but we are out of time, so we can't wait for it.  There are low-cost, low-carbon forms of energy available today even though you don't like them for some reason.

text:
As a scientist specializing in the study of atmospheric physics, I have to tell you all that,
despite his qualifications, Brian Cox has failed to look into what are false
claims by climatologists in regard to the conjecture that radiation from one
molecule of carbon dioxide in every 2,500 other air molecules causes heat
transfer from the cold atmosphere to the already warmer surface and raises the
temperature thereof. I have spoken personally to Brian Cox and given him the
link to my papers at @t but he remains arrogant
and narcissistic in regard to his worship of NASA and the infant science of
climatology. In fact it is NASA's "energy budget" diagrams that
expose their errors because these diagrams imply that radiation from different
sources can be added in order to determine the resulting temperature. Nothing
in established physics says that can be done, and no published experiment
anywhere supports the conjecture. Cox completely ignores the work of the
brilliant physicist Josef Loschmidt who explained how gravity forms the
temperature gradient in the troposphere, not "back radiation" from
so-called "greenhouse" gases. In fact, if climatology
"science" were correct we could calculate that the main "greenhouse"
gas, water vapor, ought to make rain forests 50 to 80 degrees hotter than
deserts. In fact, my study in my 2013 paper "Planetary Core and Surface
Temperatures" indicates that water vapor cools us, as can be shown using
long-established physics as in that paper. You can learn more from my website
@t and I suggest watching my videos
@ and
@ as indeed
should Brian Cox. Also watch¬†@
author: Douglas Cotton

text: "A simple and smart way to fix climate change". So, we'll just switch to solar and wind energy, right? How many millions of acres of solar "farms" will be needed. How many huge wind turbines? That is, in addition to the really simple things we can do like more efficient transportation systems, insulating all buildings, efficient lighting, etc. Then we'll need huge battery systems due to the irregular production of energy from industrial wind and solar. What will it all cost? Hey, just asking. If the answers aren't known, then maybe it's not so simple and smart. And, are there no environmental costs to covering vast areas of the land with industrial wind and solar? I suggest there are. Not saying it shouldn't happen, but let's not ignore such costs. Here in Massachusetts, thousands of acres of fields and forests have been converted to solar "farms" with immense ecological damage. These acres no longer sequester carbon nor produce oxygen nor function as wildlife habitat. Should these fact be ignored? Just asking. Dan?

text:
So this was broadcast nearly five years ago, and since then the USA, which is the world's major producer of Co2 emissions, even if a lot of their pollution is contracted out to China, has not only done precisely nothing (a few electric cars in California and some wind turbines don't really count) but the Climate Change deniers have now gained total control of the Executive branch of government. Also, a staggeringly high proportion of US citizens are so divorced from reality that they effectively live in a parallel universe of blissful (and wilful) ignorance - although the impact of their insanity still affects this universe where the sane people live. 

Mr Miller's proposal is a variation on the carbon levy/carbon trading idea but the notion of dividing the dividend equally ignores the realities of power politics. Of course it makes some sense, but the USA decided last year to have an enormous tax cut and to give the proceeds almost exclusively to the wealthiest sections of society, while the enormous cost of this will be borne by the working man and women and the poorest will suffer the most. In such a society, where greed, corruption and mass ignorance dominate the political landscape, how does anyone think that distributing a dividend equally is ever going to make it through the current system of government by plutocracy?

This proposal also fails to address the reality that a cultural change also needs to take place and that our current economic models need to be altered to dethrone GDP growth as the sole or primary measure of economic success. I don't know whether we have passed too many tipping points already (though this is entirely possible) but I do know that changing people's expectations and aspirations is an enormously difficult thing to do and that the cult of individualistic greed and consumption that is so prevalent in Western societies (and rapidly spreading to non-western societies as well) is utterly incompatible with the absolute necessity for collaborative and collective measure to mitigate the impacts of Climate Change and Global warming that are already well under way and will result in mass starvation and a refugee crisis and unprecedented population movements that will topple all liberal democracies in Europe and Asia within decades unless we take drastic action now. Modern capitalism works on the basis of everlasting economic growth, ever-growing levels of debt and by pushing the externalities off the balance sheet for someone else to pick up. This lunacy cannot be sustained and is going to kill a large proportion of the human race (possibly up to 100%... I don't know) unless we act decisively and rapidly, so I'm not sure that this idea, good as it is, really meets the needs of our dire emergency.

¬†@Dan Miller¬†, plants were stunted when CO2 levels were 280 ppm.  They were stunted when CO2 levels were 350 ppm.  And, they are stunted today with CO2 levels around 410 ppm.  Plants would do much better if CO2 levels were over 1600 ppm.  We would be better off too, and yet no warmer than now, all other things being constant.

What makes you think we won't do well if we keep increasing CO2?  At what level of CO2 do you think we will start to have difficulties?
author: Ron_the_Skeptic

text:
¬†@Ron_the_Skeptic¬† Plants were not stunted for the past 8000 years, during the development of civilization and agriculture.  If you actually believe that, please provide links to your references.

What levels will we start to have problems?  How about 410 ppm?: (1) Summer Arctic sea ice volume is down 70% in the past 30 years; (2) Extremely Hot Summers (3-sigma more than the mean) have increased 5000% in the past 50 years (not a model or prediction... it already happened); (3) there is increased drought and flooding that is impacting people around the world; (4) the last time CO2 was 410 ppm, sea levels were 75 feet higher than today.  I could go on, but you get the idea... well, one more: We have warmed +1¬∫C so far on the way to 3~4¬∫C this century and more after that... The last time the Earth warmed +6¬∫C (252 million years ago), 90% of life on Earth perished.

Based on what I know, I believe that Al Gore sugar coats the situation and it will be far worse, far sooner than he implies.  And when he says the debate is over, he is correct... there is no more debate about the existence of man-made climate change within the climate science community (though regular folks continue to debate it in YouTube comments., etc.).  The volume of the summer Arctic sea ice is 70% less than it was just 30 years ago.  That's because of climate change.  Do you have an alternative explanation?  It's not the Sun (which has actually been a bit more dim the past few decades) and it's not volcanoes.  We have increased the CO2 concentration of the atmosphere by more than 40% and CO2 is a greenhouse gas, so we really shouldn't be surprised that it's getting warmer!

text:
Please help me understand the basic science behind this issue. What exactly does the following statement mean (and imply?)?:
"Earth's oceans, forests and other ecosystems continue to soak up about half the carbon dioxide emitted into the atmosphere by human activities, even as those emissions have increased, according to a study by University of Colorado and NOAA scientists to be published August 2, 2012 in the journal¬†Nature."
Does this mean that nature has the ability to COMPLETELY absorb SOME degree of carbon dioxide, such that human-caused global warming would NEVER EVER occur if the population of Earth had never exceeded the "carrying capacity" of the Earth? In other words, If the population of the Earth (pre-tipping points) had suddenly dropped and then stabilized permanently at  just 1000 Americans, and those 1000 Americans continued to use fossil fuels at their current rates, would those 1000 Americans and their replacements eventually cause global warming, or would the Earth's natural carbon dioxide absorption abilities prevent that from EVER happening?
If the latter is true, then those 1000 people and their replacements could continue to use fossil fuels until total depletion occurred without that ever having caused global warming, and therefore neither fossil fuel use alone nor overpopulation alone could be considered be the root cause of global warming. Instead, only [fossil fuel use PLUS overpopulation] (requires both) could be, since if EITHER contributing factor is removed, global warming from fossil fuel use does not occur.
If this is true, then focusing on reducing fossil fuel use just misleads the public into thinking that belt-tightening and renewable resources are the way to solve this problem, when focusing on reducing our population would be far more productive, and would collaterally solve many other problems.

text: The moment he says, "grow the economy," he illustrates that he's at least partially a scientific diletante.  Ecosystems have always been characterized by their "carrying capacity."  It's clear that from the standpoint of eco-economics that the planet as a whole has one as well. The planet's carrying capacity is defined by the rates of both resource extraction and waste deposition as applied to this fantasy of continued economic growth. We already require more than one planet's worth of resources and waste absorption capacity, and it's taking its toll on other species; you can't blow holes in the web of life without consequences, particularly for food production.  This neglect of the mandate to curb consumption places this talk (like many TED  talks) into the realm of the half-baked.

text: We can stop the man made part of climate change in its tracks in five years. In the same action we can eliminate food shortages and provide potable water for millions who now find it almost impossible to acquire. There are currently a few dozen people putting 100% of their efforts into doing just that. The process? Reversal of just 50% of desertification would do that and more. Grass and trees absorb huge quantities of CO2. As we desertify large  swaths of the planet we are in fact commiting suicide. The methods to reverse that desertification differ in small part depending on where on earth you're doing it, but the  differences are minimal. This CAN and IS being done today. text:
¬†@Jo√£o de Lemos¬† It should not be difficult to understand that there is an amount of CO2 in the atmosphere (~280 ppm) that civilization developed under.  It is now about 415 ppm and that is higher than anytime when man walked the Earth and is leading to warming that is causing sea level rise, heat waves, droughts, floods, and other extreme weather... and it will get much worse.  Scientists almost universally agree with this and simple physics explains why it is so.  The proper amount of CO2 is necessary for life, but too much will kill you and that is almost what happened to the Apollo 13 astronauts (see the movie).  Water is also necessary for life but drink too much and you will die.  Just because CO2 is necessary for life does not mean that too much of it can't cause damage.

Also, no one says that a zero emissions planet will avoid climate change.  We can't avoid it because it is already here and the excess CO2 we already put in the atmosphere will remain there for hundreds to thousands of years.  But going to net zero emissions may stop things from getting worse.  Actually, we need negative emissions if we want to avoid the bad impacts of climate change.

text:
This is a silly suggestion. Politics is simply the way a society allocates resources and manages it's economy (thus dividing resources and rewards). 


Science requires resources to be done, especially modern science, which requires large investments in manpower and equipment. Basic scientific research doesn't command private investment primarily because it usually cannot be patented and made profitable, so basic research must be funded by the society overall, meaning politics, or it won't get done. 


Getting private big money and corporate money out of politics is, however, a good first step toward making scientific funding less political.

text:
Climate change is happening as it has happened for millions of years, every scientist on earth can and will agree about that. That climate change is caused predominantly or even significantly by the man-made production of carbon dioxide is untrue. To say it is true is unjustified (there is a absence of scientific evidence for this claim) There is no consensus among climate scientists that an increase in carbon dioxide on the earth is largely responsible for climate change, in fact  most climate scientist dispute or outright deny this claimed correlation. 


Scaremongering.

"A heatwave linked to global warming killed...."  Yes, the sun plays a part in global warming and also in climate change.
Tourist seeing former islands through a glass bottom boat.  Fifteen feet rise in sea level. Sea level has been rising at the same rate since the end of the last ice age, for more than 10,000 years and despite the claim that we have gone beyond a 'tipping point' in ice melt, no increase in the rate of sea rise has been detected in the past ten years.  

The "solution". Taxes and tariffs to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 50%.  "We" are going to be in charge of collecting and distributing this money back to the people who paid it, so that they can invest in solar power etc. Are there any saps out there? 

Have you heard about the guy who cut 1m off a plank and then attached it to the other end in order to lengthen it by 1m? Same logic - labour and materials (like dowels and glue) cost nothing and nor did the time spent carrying out this pointless task or the tools to do it. Reducing carbon dioxide emissions, which now have a tiny effect on global warming and won't make any impact at all on climate change. To quote this guy "the carbon dioxide now in the atmosphere will be there for hundreds if not thousands of years". I am pleased that he pointed out that he is not a scientist, but it should be common knowledge that plants feed on carbon dioxide, it is necessary for all life, it is not a pollutant.

text:
This is a tax and taxes do not help solve the problem.  It is an incentive like saying "We will rob you if you do not SOMEHOW lower your carbon footprint."  Money is not the solution.  
   8 things will help:
        1.  Solar power for the home and car and power stations will drop the need for fossil fuels to a manageable level.  Every house and business can run on the amount of sun that hit's one half of it's roof.   Tall buildings reap the height of it's walls and can use the panels to block the heat of the sun from coming in without obstructing the view, and in the winter time be raised up a few feet to allow needed heat in.  
       2  Wind power, it is not merely for the large application but can be adapted for homes as well.  In FLagstaff Arizona the winds pick up to around 40 to 45 mph in the evenings, it is a tremendous amount of energy to gain from.  In the winter the winds are strong in the north where there is less sun.
   3.  Thorium is a viable replacement for Uranium based Nuclear power and is safer by far.   Power plants produce huge amounts of emissions not to mention heat and other pollutants that start from the gathering of fossil fuels to it's refinement, deliver and consumption, all produce pollution. Finding replacements to power plants is a huge part of the solution. 
        4. Hydroelectric.  5 Geothermal, which can work in hot zones in California as well as Yellowstone Wyoming.  
     5.  Another means of solar energy is solar collection by means of mirrors to heat salt water to steam.                                 .     6.  Reforestation and saving forests not only help disburse heat but absorb Co2.  
      7.  Electric cars, trucks, Semis and even passenger planes are now all becoming electric,  Even Buses are going electric.  The main issue for a long time has been the batteries, but really the whole system has improved with more efficient electronic controllers, chargers, and motors and there are yet more things to try to get more mileage from an electric car.  But the batteries have made the largest jump in the last 10 years and are being improved even today with a potential of getting 600 miles on a charge at best to a thousand in the near future.  Tesla is the leading industry in this area and recently purchased the Ulra Capacitor factory... something K I think,  but they have made such improvements as to add significantly to the range of a battery pack.  There are still new milestones being reached every few months so that the current batteries will be out paced by the following year.  All , hopefully will bring the price down .  The upper 20 K is the lower limit to a decent electric today with Tesla's being the mid 30 K range up to 250,000 for the fastest production car in the world.  0 to 60 in 1.9 seconds and close to 600 mile ranges available.  Tesla has also made a large domestic truck and the full size Semi Truck for hauling goods cross country with the same 600 mile range on a single charge.  More and more charging stations are going up all over the world as we speak.
   There are over a dozen electric plane models flying today, some with over 300 mile ranges but could improve that with solar assist and one of Teslas improved battery packs.  There is also talk of en electric Jet engine .   There is still a need for fossil fuels in some high energy  applications such as  Tanks, fighter jets, massive transport planes and vehicles, air craft carriers and the like, though some are going nuclear.
     8.  Recyling.  Plastics mostly.  With what I throw away in 2 liter bottles every year I could build a shed out of it.  It could be melted down and extruded into 2, 3, and 4 inch clear tubing strong enough to build with.  Or square pipe stock for more practical construction.  Metal, paper and Glass are others that are getting recycled but not on a grand enough scale.  That island of plastic in the pacific ocean is a gold mine of hydrocarbons and plastics to be sorted and made into building materials.

text: It's hard to cover everything in a 15 minute talk.  What evidence are you looking for?  Atmospheric CO2 levels are higher than they have been for millions of years (before humans walked the Earth) and almost all of the 10 warmest years since record keeping began all occurred in the last 10 years.  And while "the climate has always changed" the current change is happening 10~100 times faster than in past "natural" changes.  There are lots of talks available on the physics of climate change... Check out Gavin Schmidt's TED talk.

   A stove burns at 450 degrees and will dissipate water from any size pot over a duration of time. Since a 450 degree stove can dissipate water from a pot then a 2,000 degree jet engine will eliminate water at a much faster rate. Water is heavier then atmosphere at ground level and is exponentially heavier than the atmosphere where all jets traverse. All jets traverse the atmosphere at 25,000 to 45,000 feet elevation. The higher the altitude the thinner the atmosphere. 
   THIINK and CALCULATE those numbers and facts with relation to 166,000 jet engines producing 2,000 degrees of extreme heat in the thin layer of the planets atmosphere every second of every minute of every hour of everyday of the year - NON-STOP!!!!

Well, a jet engine is just a fancy propeller but the propeller is inside the engine instead of outside.

text:
¬†@Orion Red¬† what I have to lose is my time arguing with people who have their mind made up. I've been arguing this on the internet since the mid-2000s and actually created a thread that went over 6,000 posts at one point. I don't need to argue this anymore because events have proven my position to be correct. The amount of evidence that's come out since 2010 is staggering. You can even say the science has been settled. Climate change is real and it's been happening since the dawn of time. Sadly a lot of young people that don't realize that things go in Cycles seem to think that the current cycle is the end. It's not. It's a cycle. So you continue going on believing whatever you want to believe and who you want to believe I prefer to trust the data. Anyone who actually looks at the date of themself without trusting the interpretations of others realizes what a farce the entire agw religion is all about. Here's a fun one for you

Whenever your local weatherman says that today is the hottest day in over a hundred yearsoh, don't say to yourself oh my God the planet is burning up. Brother ask yourself, how hot was it back then. There is a reason Greenland is called Greenland. And there is a reason why the United States had the Dust Bowl in the 1930s. And there is a reason why we were scared to death of global warming in the thirties but then we were scared to death of global cooling in the seventies and then in the early 2000s we were scared of global warming again. It's cyclical.
And here's another real challenge for everyone. Risk analysis as part of my job. There are three factors to consider. First is the likelihood of a thing happening. Second is the impact of a thing happening. And third is the cost of mitigating the risk. This is why we don't Harden our houses against a meteor strike. The results would be catastrophic. But the cost of mitigation would also be catastrophic. We wouldn't have enough money left over to feed ourselves. The same issue is at play with the agw religion. The risk of all the bad stuff happening gets smaller and smaller as predictions failed to come true. But the cost is astronomical.

Especially in third world countries that are trying to become second world countries.

And here is the big points. At the end of the day this is about control. If you can convince the general public that carbon dioxide is actually a poisonous gas to the planet, and get them to an able you to control the production of carbon dioxide, you have caused them to allow you to control every aspect of human life. The reason is simple. Virtually everything people do results in some amount of carbon dioxide. Don't be fooled, this is an attempt to totally control the entire Human Race by convincing us that carbon dioxide is a pollutant. Do you want to know what warms our planet? Atmospheric pressure. That's why Mars and Venus, both of which have the same percentage of carbon dioxide in their atmospheres, have such wildly different temperatures. And why the temperature at the lowest reaches of Jupiter's atmosphere are so incredibly hot even though it's so far from the sun. It's why the Grand Canyon is so much harder at the base then it is up at the top. It's why mountain tops are so cold even though they have so much direct sunlight.

text:
The other countries wouldn't add tariffs to respond because the tariffs would apply to domestic goods as well so there would be no competitive disadvantage to trade so another country would have no reason to add a retaliatory tariff. 

If you charge tariffs on say steel coming from other countries than that hurts the other countries ability to sell steel to you but if you charge a tariff on imported and domestic steel at an equal amount than it doesn't cost the other country any business at all. The other country doesn't pay the tariff, even the businesses in those countries selling goods don't pay it. The people that pay the tariffs are the consumers and as long as their is no competitive disadvantage to trade it won't cost the other country anything to have a tariff attached to a carbon fee. It will just incentivize them to charge the same carbon fee so the money goes to their coffers instead of ours but ultimately it's always the consumer who pays.

text:
Climate change is real, but there is dispute about some points this gentleman makes. His sea level rise numbers are based upon the''solid Earth'' paradigm.  In fact, the Earth is more accurately a liquid filled balloon-like body. There are some experts who believe the additional weight at the ocean bottoms brought on by melting ice caps  will cause the ocean bottoms to sink and the land masses to rise - essentially to bulge outward, balloon-like in response to the bottom squeezing.


Secondly, there is already small success in Australia, Israel and in sub-Saharan Africa to reverse desertification. If we expanded/accelerated that effort through investment in  desalination,  we could increase carbon capture by a big percentage. 


Also, there has been talk of seeding the ocean surfaces with iron compounds - to promote the growth of algae. This could sequester a large percentage of carbon, which would ultimately sink to the ocean floors as the algae died.


Don't write us off yet.

text:
CO2 has no effect on temperature.  Convection and conduction from the ground vs radiation that extinguishes in 40 feet makes NO difference in total heat.  Sorry the theory is 100% wrong.  The absorption of CO2 is 10 months if you do a Fourier analysis of Mauna Loa Data.  Most estimates are less than 10 years, average is 5.  CO2 is all gone in worst case in 10 years from man.  The reason it is goes up has nothing to do with man.  It is a function of Ocean Water temperature.  Simple chemistry.  Stomata data from plants shows 400 ppm is common and it goes up and down in cycles of 60-80 years.  We are nearing the end of a cycle.  Ice core data is not correct at 280 ppm.  

Putting a price on CO2 ("carbon") will actually delay real solutions.  My engine can get you 4x less fuel per distance than an old car.  It is also less CO2 than an EV while using gasoline.  To get to zero CO2 you need nuclear and electro-fuels, fuels made from electricity.  If you want Jet fuel, you need a supply of CO2, which can be found in Ocean Water.  The Navy will be making jet fuel on aircraft carrier soon.  If you want NH3 (ammonia) you have N2 in the air (78%), which you can make via solar from home.  Either fuel would run the world.  Put nuclear on coast and make Jet fuel (can be used in Diesel engines) or make NH3 inland at home with my new engine.  

We need eletro-fuels for products to replace oil.  This is a key technology that is required to get to zero new CO2.  Batteries will not help or lower CO2 output.  Plug to wheel for my engine in car vs Electric Vehicle is less via NH3 than with battery.  NH3 can store 12,000 Kwh in a 1000 gallon tank that costs $1500, vs a L-ion battery at $2.4 million.  A 1600 times cost multiple.  NH3 IS the battery.  Fuel IS the battery.  Just make it via nuclear and you have zero CO2.  

But again, CO2 is entirely beneficial and more is better.  1200 ppm is much better for earth than 400.  The reason to go nuclear and electro-fuel without batteries (toxic nightmare in the future) is to allow low cost energy for all.  If all the world wanted oil based energy we would have oil at $200/barrel and high fuel costs.  Batteries can't work in airplanes due to weight.  NH3 and Jet fuel can.  

Problem is rather easy to solve.  Nuclear + my engine + electro fuels.   This video has no solution and is totally wrong about CO2.  Happy to discuss it.

text: The issue is not CO2's absorption of emitted radiation within 40 feet of the surface.  The issue is the altitude at which absorption saturation breaks down.  The higher the concentration, the higher the altitude.  The higher the altitude, the lower the emitting temperature.  The lower the emitting temperature, the lower the emission intensity to outer space.  Fewer watts emitted mean more watts retained in the climate system.  It should not surprise you that your superficial dismissal of a century of climate science is flawed.  You made a typical rookie error.  But no doubt you believe in yourself with full confidence.

text:
What this guy doesn't understand is that CO2 is not pollution!  He also doesn't understand CO2 is required by plants and they are constantly removing all the CO2 that reaches them.  He also doesn't understand methane turns into CO2.  He doesn't understand the amount of CO2 has to be doubled again and again to get the same effect.  Apparently he also doesn't know commercial greenhouses pump CO2 into their buildings to improve plant growth while reducing water consumption.  
This guy doesn't understand economics either!  Tariffs are paid by the citizens of the country imposing the tax, not by the exporting country.
There is no climate tipping point.  Here is 600 million years worth of CO2 and temperature data.  If 5% CO2 didn't cause some magic tipping point, then increasing CO2 from 0.04% to 0.05% or even to 1% were that possible, is not going to cause some tipping point.  We are barely above the least amount of CO2 that Earth has experienced and there are those who would try to make you believe adding some CO2 into this drought is going to destroy our climate.

author: TheAmazingchickens

text:
¬†@David Anewman¬† communism, as defined by Karl Marx, is a stateless, classless society; it has never existed and is basically a thought experiment.

The aim of socialism is to try and get to that stateless and classless society (or your Lenin quote), but there is allot of disagreement about how to do this.

The social/economic system of the USSR was not Communism and the Soviet government says this, in fact USSR stands for: United Socialist Soviet Republic.

The Government of the USSR was socialist (although many leftists will debate this), specifically a sort of authoritarian socialism called Marxism Leninism that believes in enforcing a one party state.

Socialism doesn't have to be especially authoritarian though, there are other forms of socialism like democratic socialism that believes in different methods of leadership and representation.

There is also Anarchism, which whilst technically not socialist, also believes in bringing about communism albeit in a radically different and more direct way.

One important thing to understand about socialism is how it's meaning has been warped in modern popular discourse; Bernie Sanders political platform, for example, is not socialist (idk about the man himself), but instead social democratic, representing more of a balance between private and public ownership of the economy, than socialism's complete public ownership.

text:
¬†@Dan Miller¬†, yes, if you drink 3 gallons of water at once you might die.  Or you might be one of those who can drink an amazing amount of beer, which is mostly water, with little or no ill effects.  Where did you get the notion that about 280 ppm is the correct amount of CO2? Or that "Too much CO2 will not be fine"?  How much do you think is too much?  I think 2% is too much, and somewhere between 1600 ppm and 1.5% would be the right amount.  If about 280 ppm were the correct amount none of the commercial greenhouse operations would be paying for CO2, almost all of them are!  They give their plants between 1200 and 1600 ppm.
Since there is no scientific evidence that CO2 has any effect on temperature in the real world, why do you think "Too much CO2 will not be fine"?
author: Ron_the_Skeptic

text: ¬†@Ron_the_Skeptic¬† Well, the last time CO2 was 410 ppm (today's value), sea levels were about 75 feet higher than today.  Would you consider that a good thing?  Yes, more CO2 -- everything else left unchanged -- helps plants grow, but more CO2 (less than 1600 ppm) warmed the world 252 million years ago to +6¬∫C and 90% of life on Earth perished.  That warming took tens of thousands of years to happen.  We are doing it in 100 to 200 years.  How much CO2 is OK?  Climate scientist Jim Hansen said that 350 ppm is the highest level that is possibly safe (and that may be too high too).  Civilization developed in a remarkably stable climate over the past several thousand years.  We are now entering new territory.  It's not going to be pretty.

text:
Yours is not a new idea, but it is completely unworkable. Consumers can switch away from fossil fuels for their car but that just means the problem is returned to the electric production plant since the majority of our electricity continues to come from fossil fuels. The carbon idea  has been studied extensively, including foreign attempts to implement it, but it hasn't even come close to working well anywhere. Consumers can  switch to wind or solar, but since these energy forms are intermittent, they must have extensive standby capacity particularly in the areas where most Americans actually live.  Usually this standby capacity will be natural gas fired, but natural gas is 90% as bad as coal.  Meanwhile all consumers will be requesting their subsidy for switching, while real actual costs have gone up materially and their is no one willing to pay the fee.  The real cost of retaining facilities whose use will be intermittent is very high and will be passed by utilities back to consumers.

There is only one solution - a massive program to build nuclear power plants. Few like this idea, but its the only one that produces real changes in CO2 levels.

author: Dan Miller

text:
First of all, electric vehicles (EVs) are much more efficient than internal combustion engine (ICE) cars since they don't product heat from combustion.  And while wind and solar are intermittent, they are less expensive than fossil fuel energy, can supply much of our energy without storage, and low cost storage is becoming available now (large batteries are replacing natural gas "peaker" plants).  It will be much easier to replace a few hundred power plants with clean alternatives than it will be to replace 100s of millions of cars.  We should switch to EVs now.  Also, EVs are better than ICE cars is almost every way... performance, safety, maintenance costs, fuel costs, functionality, and fun!
Nuclear is fine except it is much more expensive than renewables, takes a really long time to build, and people have an irrational fear of it.
author: Dan Miller

text: ¬†@Dan Miller¬†ou have misunderstood what efficiency is. True, electric motors are not hot as are internal combustion engines. But that doesn't make them more efficient, since ic's get a far higher ratio of energy inputs converted to energy outputs. Your views on  the cost of wind and solar are also incorrect since they don't reflect  true costs. In addition to the high costs of maintaining separate generation facilities to compensate for their intermittent periods, the nation would have to buy storage facilities roughly equivalent to one house on every block in the land -- empty it of family and replace it with batteries. Also note that the existing grid supplies electricity made from fossil fuels with natural gas being the worst offender. There is no point in converting the car fleet to electric vehicles until the grid is ready. Finally while we both agree electric vehicles are a very good thing, the even bigger problem is to get rid of fossil fuels in the industrial, commercial, and utility stationary source markets. This requires a huge investment and it would ruin the amelioration if a giant slug of it were invested in wind and solar since the money would have to ultimately be spent on something that solved the problem.  Please think all these things through. Our nation may be rich but it is not rich enough to afford a couple of generations being spent investing in the wrong technologies.

text: He says CO2 concentration in the atmosphere is too high, let's call it 400 parts per million (PPM) right now.  He says the 400 PPM level is causing climate change.  The goal would be to reduce it to early 1800's levels, call it 200 PPM, where it is believed the climate will stay normal.  The problem he doesn't mention is reduction of CO2 input to the atmosphere will not stop or even reduce climate change until the level is below a certain PPM limit, to be determined, but let's say it has to be 200 PPM.  Even total cessation of man-made CO2 will not lower PPM levels rapidly enough to prevent severe climate change, this is called the passive approach.  From a standing start, it will take nature over 100 years to reduce the excess level by HALF, 400 years to reduce it to early 1800's levels.  And of course the whole world economy will crash to a halt and billions will die of starvation, disease and chaos.  What to do?  Instead of passively reducing CO2, ACTIVELY reduce it !!!!!  Nature removes CO2 all the time and puts it into the ground using TREES, trillions and trillions of trees.  We should stop cutting down all trees.  We should plant MORE trees anywhere we can.  An Apollo project of tree planting!  We can develop trees to create hybrids that eat the most CO2 for their cost.  We can also pull CO2 out of the air the way it's done inside nuclear submarines with CO2 scrubbers.  That takes huge amounts of electricity which can be generated with solar and wind and waves and (egads!) nuclear power.  We should make it an international crime of the highest magnitude to destroy rain forests, international armies should constantly patrol to protect the Amazon, the African and the South East Asian rain forests.  Execute slash and burn croppers at the halftime of the Super Bowl !!!  Green the deserts of the world with trees, provide habitat for animals, recreation areas for people, lots of CO2 being eaten and lots of oxygen added to the air.  Climate change avoided. Your welcome.

text: Additional co2 could lead to a warmer world but would have little impact on the long-term hydrological system. Scientists tell us the ice was over a mile thick in the last ice age and the sea level was much lower. Where did the energy come from to evaporate that volume of water and transport it to deposit it as snow in the higher latitudes? Not from a world warmed by fossil fuels because we were not around at the time. It came from the sun that emits approximately nine watts more energy than the earth re-emits. Ice melts at approximately four degrees Celsius and when the ice age ice melted it filled the oceans with cold water. The sun warms the oceans over millennia and will continue to do so regardless of any action by mankind. Heated ocean water evaporates forming clouds which transport it to higher latitudes where it falls as rain or snow. The more the oceans warm the greater amount of rain and snow is created. As the oceans diminish the snow accumulates until there is insufficient water in the oceans to maintain the rate of evaporation and snowfall. leading to the melting of the ice thereby maintaining the cycle.

author: WeDontThink

text: As the fee increases the cost of fossil fuels, low-carbon alternatives become more competitive (and they are already competitive... the majority of new electricity generation comes from wind and solar).  So while fee and dividend will grow the economy and that will create some demand for new energy, most of the new supply will come from low-carbon sources.  And when the fee gets high enough, it will be cheaper to offset fossil use with capturing CO2 from the atmosphere rather than pay the fee... that's when emissions will drop dramatically.
author: Dan Miller

text: The reason for giving all the money back to the public is to allow the fee to grow to a sizable amount (~$100/ton) with public support.  A $100/ton price on CO2 will transform energy production and transportation far more than a lower carbon price with government subsidies.  Politicians won't be able to implement a high enough price on carbon if the money is kept and used by the government.

text:
First I want to thank you for taking the time to respond to my comment. I hope we can have a debate without the name calling trolls jumping in.  
I have many questions about this system and hope you don‚Äôt mind entertaining my curiosity. You made a biiiig assumption that I don‚Äôt disagree with the policy, anytime someone has an idea that gives the government more money and another reason to get bigger, I have problems!
You say the government will absorb the costs involved with implementing this program, where will that money come from? The government does not have their own $$ only what the taxpayers give them so that $$ comes from US.
You say everyone gets a check (and thank you for adding LEGAL citizens!) will that include those that don‚Äôt own homes or cars? People in apartments, condos, elderly housing, dorms, etc. will not be able to put solar panels on the roof and will only need a few LED bulbs. I know a lot of elderly people that either don‚Äôt own cars or don‚Äôt drive very much so their checks are going to be spent at the casino. Do you think the 21 year old in college will be buying LED bulbs? Perhaps  the first month but then what? Beer?  More than likely. I say this somewhat tongue in cheek but you KNOW some of the money, possibly a lot of the money, is going to be spent foolishly. I can see a large portion of the money being used to pay bills, fix the broken fence, buy the kids school clothes, etc. It will help people, I just wonder how much it will help the planet.
You go on to add that big corporations will be paying heavily into the system but will not receive a check. Do you really think that the likes of the Walton‚Äôs will see their delivery costs go up without making some sort of correction at the register? Your figure of ten cents a gallon works out to be roughly 3%, I can‚Äôt imagine a huge corporation like Walmart not correcting for a 3% increase in delivery costs. Do you suppose that correction will be just the 3% or will companies add another percentage point or two just to be on the safe side? Now everyone is paying more for EVERYTHING and that will be money that does not make it into this system.
How much do you think we will get every month? Even if it‚Äôs a check for $1000 will that make Bill Gates buy solar panels? I would expect that people with his financial horsepower would have already made the changes you propose if they really wanted to, a miniscule check every month is not going to sway them.  I hear Al Gore spends $2,400 a month to heat/cool his 20 room mansion. How much will it take him to convert to solar?
I wish I had your faith in my fellow citizens to do the right thing with this money. I wish that I could envision a government program that could work efficiently and stay small. 
Thanks for taking the time to enlighten me!
author: towerclock

text:
While people can buy LED bulbs, etc. with their dividend check, that is not the main thing that reduces emissions.  Right now, the price of fossil fuels does not include their "external costs" that are paid by society (you, me, and everyone else).  For example, the health costs of coal power in West Virgina (not including climate impacts) exceeds the value of the electricity produced!  So, while fossil fuels are "cheap", they are actually one of the most expensive forms of energy.  These external costs are real and must be paid through higher insurance premiums, uninsured losses, food prices, health care costs, and taxes (to pay extreme weather events, droughts, floods, etc).  Because of this mispricing of fossil fuels, our economy runs less efficiently and that reduces jobs and incomes for most Americans. 

Fee and Dividend helps correct this mispricing and makes the price of fossil fuels more closely match the cost of using such fuels.  By raising the price of fossil fuels, clean alternatives such as wind and solar will be more competitive and will be selected by utilities (and corporations such as Walmart) more often as they phase out "expensive" fossil fuels.  A price on the carbon content of fossil fuels will also make new technologies such as carbon capture commercially feasible.

So, the success of Fee and Dividend does not depend on people spending their dividend checks on "green" things, though many will because it will save them money!

On a side note, you should reconsider your fear of government spending.  States that tax and spend more (like California) have better economies and incomes than states that have lower taxes and spending.  The experiment has been done and the results are clear.  This effect is also true on the country level.  The highest taxed countries (e.g., Scandinavian countries) have great economies and their citizens are "happier" than those in lower taxed countries. But in any case, Fee and Dividend does not provide any money to the government and, as you point out, it costs the government a little bit to run the program.  The good news is that the extra taxes collected because of Fee and Dividend's positive impact on GDP (growing it by $1.4 trillion over 20 years) will more than pay for the small cost to run the program.

It will be nearly impossible for the government to "devour" the collected revenues.  Every legal resident gets the same check and there are only two numbers that matter: the total amount collected and the number of legal residents (divide the two and you get the amount that everyone gets).  Since everyone gets the same amount, it will be nearly impossible for the government to take some of the money for other purposes.

text:
I have spoken across the country. Author, scientist, inventor, engineer from the number one university in the country and an ordained minister. Magazines, newspapers, radio, television. And, with all due respect people having been saying the same things for decades. I wrote the plan that became the foundation of air quality plans and climate change plans adopted by cities across Canada. I have the letters from the David Suzuki foundation, Jack Layton, The United Nations University and ministers for both federal and provincial levels to validate it. 

We already have a carbon tax. Here, it is called the HST. Every single gallon of gas, kilowatt of power, individual income, groceries bought and consumed. Every single tool used to serve us, every light switch you buy. Every pizza delivered. All taxed. 

I have decided to speak tonight. Government has, as their goal, take a problem and create a revenue stream from it. From you - from your pocket. They treat climate change as a business case without merit. Nothing that has been done after billions of dollars taken from your wallets has reduced emissions. They tax you on solar, wind, geothermal, clean fuels, and on. Zero environmental or health effects. Population dynamics alone - it is just either government, business, or both. Opportunities for profit.

So, here it is. These people talk but accomplish nothing tangible. They never have. Stage lights. Carpet. Later a bit of TV.

Life is not television.  My company works to save thousands of lives per day - I live in the world where where math becomes metal and the names of those people I am working for are as important as yours and your children. We get it done and don't just talk about it. 

We already have tax.

author: Dan Miller

text:
First of all, Judith Curry is part of the denialsphere.  But back to your question.  About 26% of the emitted CO2 is absorbed fairly quickly by the oceans (not the specific emitted molecules, but an amount of CO2 equal to about a third of the emitted CO2).  This makes the oceans more acidic.  About 28% is absorbed by plants and soils.  The remaining CO2 (about half of the amount emitted) stays in the atmosphere for hundreds to thousands of years (again, not necessarily the specific emitted molecules).  But what really matters is the warming caused by the emitted CO2.  The National Academy of Sciences says that the warming impact of emitted CO2 remains at full force for about 1000 years and slowly declines over the next 10,000 years.  

Why does the warming last longer than the CO2 residency time?  Warming causes the Earth to release more CO2 and that CO2 lasts a long time.  So CO2 causes warming that starts a process that emits more CO2 that causes more warming.

author: Dan Miller

text:
Your electric bill may go up by $10/month and everything else you buy (fuel, food, clothes, iPhones, etc.) may go up by, say $70/month.  But you'll get back about $100/month in the dividend.  And note that you still have the incentive to use less energy or purchase lower-cost renewable energy and save even more.

Your company will indeed not get a dividend and you will pass on your higher costs to consumers.  But as shown above, those consumers make more on the dividend than they pay in higher prices.

If you're wealthy and generate a lot of CO2 (multiple homes, fly a lot), then you will pay more in higher prices than you get back in the dividend, but you won't care much about that if you're wealthy.

The alternative is to let global temperatures and sea levels to keep rising.  Those costs will be many, many orders of magnitude more than cost of the carbon fees.
author: Dan Miller

text: Every individual gets an equal dividend. So some people will say it's a redistribution. Minnesota is less than ideal for solar losing its punch in the Winter when energy is needed for heating. text: The breakeven income where you earn more with the dividend than you pay in higher prices may vary a bit depending on where you live (rural vs. urban, hot vs. cold) but still almost all lower income people and most middle class people will come out ahead.  And remember we will do this to solve a big problem.  If you are one of the people who would pay slightly more than you get back, you still will pay (and are paying) for the very high external costs of fossil fuels through higher taxes (to pay for Katrina, Sandy, etc.), higher insurance costs, higher uninsured losses, higher food prices, etc.  As they say, "You can pay be now or you can pay me [much, much more] later."
author: Dan Miller

The 1% are going to be screwed by climate change like the rest of us, though they might have a few extra years of protection. text: Well, a nuclear winter has its own set of problems!  Putting aerosols in the air is being studied as a form of "geo-engineering" to cool the Earth.  While it would cool the Earth, there are many problems with this including (1) it does not address the underlying problem of too much CO2 so ocean acidification will continue to advance and the "natural state" (absent the geo-engineering)  of the world will continue to warm, (2) you must continue to put the aerosols high in the atmosphere continually for thousands of years without stopping; if you stop, there will be an almost instantaneous increase in global temperatures that will wreck havoc on the world.  Even given these problems, it is worth researching methods and impacts of this type of geo-engineering.  A better and safer form of geo-engineering is "carbon dioxide removal" (CDR) where we literally suck CO2 out of the atmosphere and put in back underground where it came from.  This is much more expensive than putting aerosols in the atmosphere but it is an actually solution and, BTW, we will need to do this to maintain a livable atmosphere!

text:
The math does work.  It's not a tax on corporations, it's a pollution fee on fossil fuels.  Right now, fossil fuels cause (and will cause) tremendous damage that the public -- not the fossil fuel companies -- pay for.  Is that fair?  If you say yes, may I dump my garbage in your yard so I don't need to pay for waste disposal?  And we would use an existing government agency to manage the program... so it would only cost a tiny fraction of the money collected.  Since the program increases GDP by $1.4 trillion, there would be plenty of extra tax money available to the government to pay for the program.

Note that an almost identical program already exists in Alaska and everyone there loves it.  It's called the Alaska Permanent Fund.

Natural CO2 is not a pollutant.  The excess CO2 (about 40 gigatons/year) that man emits is a greenhouse gas pollutant that already has increased global temperatures more than +1¬∫C.  Water is normally a good thing, but that doesn't mean that floods can't be bad.

Your comments about raw data, etc. are denier talking points and are incorrect.  Almost all climate raw data is available to the public.  The peer review process is a check on incorrect interpretations of data and checking facts.
author: Dan Miller

text:
CO2 is great.  Without CO2 in the atmosphere, the Earth would be a frozen snowball without life (well, without us, at least).  But too much CO2 in the atmosphere can drive up temperatures and other effects that will make life quite unpleasant and challenging for us.

Water is also great.  You can't live long without it.  But drink 5 gallons in an hour and you'll be dead.

Everything in moderation.
author: Dan Miller

text:

There are enough people in the US today who support action on climate change.  The problem is they don't see it as a #1 issue and they are also, obviously, quite easily fooled by disinformation.

text: We should include all costs of solar. Who pays for backing it up? Who pays the grid costs? Inverters to convert it to alternating current are expensive. Energy that is dispatchable is more valuable than that which is not.
author: Ragnaar Minnesota

text: The all-in cost of solar is competitive with fossil fuel-based electricity and is much cheaper when you consider the enormous external costs of fossil fuels.  There are issues related to putting solar on the grid as there are for putting any type of power on the grid (e.g., what do you do when you shut down a coal plant for repairs?).  Denmark is already at 50% renewables on its way to 100%.  Power engineers are smart.  It can be done.

author: Dan Miller

text: With Fee and Dividend, 100% of the money collected is returned to the public.  Note that you are already paying a "tax" on fossil fuels in the form of external costs.  You pay this "tax" through higher regular taxes to pay for weather damage (which is greatly increasing), higher insurance rates, higher uninsured losses, higher food prices, higher health insurance, etc.  And on the path we are on the external costs will include the destruction of most major cities near the ocean and many other places, collapse of food production, etc.  Are you OK paying that tax (and having your children pay even more)?
author: Dan Miller

text:
Of course the climate has changed before.  The big changes in the recent past (past million years) have been due mostly to orbital changes (causing the ice age cycles).  The periods you mentioned were regional changes, not global.  The current man-made warming is unprecedented in millions of years and comes at a time when the Sun's output is at a low point for the past century.

When you say that the climate has changed before, you are either implying that the current climate change is natural (it's not) and/or that its impacts won't be that bad (they will be catastrophic on the path we are on).

If someone commits murder, we don't say "But people have died before."  The fact that there were natural changes in the climate in the past, does not mean that the coming preventable catastrophe is somehow OK.
author: Dan Miller

Tyler:  From Wikipedia: "the timing and areas affected by the Little Ice Age suggested largely-independent regional climate changes rather than a globally-synchronous increased glaciation. At most, there was modest cooling of the Northern Hemisphere during the period."

But the warming today is comparable to the warming then, but it already includes the warming then!  We are on track for a +4¬∫C warming this century and +6¬∫C and more next century.  The last time it warmed +6¬∫C (55 million years ago), most life on Earth perished in a mass extinction event.

text:

http://www.bbc.co.uk/nature/extinction_events/Permian‚ÄìTriassic_extinction_event

"The climate has changed before" is one of the leading denier memes.  While the statement is literally true, the implications that either (1) the current climate change is natural or (2) the coming changes will be OK, are both false.

text:
At this point, we have committed ourselves to quite a bit of warming and things are going to get bad.  But, if we don't act, it could get much worse than bad.

If we do implement Fee and Dividend, there will be a renaissance in clean energy technology.  That doesn't mean the impacts of climate change go away, but it does mean we will avoid some of the even worse impacts.
author: Dan Miller

text:
The fee will make fossil fuels more expensive over time (it increases gradually each year), so more people will choose clean energy optons because they will become increasingly cheaper than fossil fuel options.  Businesses will immediately stop investing in new fossil fuel infrastructure, and instead they will invest in new clean energy technologies. text:
At 2:05 you state that Arrhenius's calculations for a warmer were about right.  He got it not about right in the paper you show.  Once Arrhenius had come across the Stefan-Boltzmann radiative-transfer equation, he was able to recalculate the matter in 1906, and published a paper that concluded thus:

"In ahnliche Weise berechne ich, dass eine Verminderung des Kohlensauregehalts zur halfte, oder eine Zunahme desselben auf den Doppelten betrag temperaturaenderungen von -1.5 K beziehungsweise +1.6 K entsprechen wurde."

Translated : "In the same way, I calculate that a halving or doubling of CO2 concentration would engender temperature change of -1.5 or +1.6 K respectively."  Not 4-8 deg C. Your prrsentation is flawed in this respect.

author: Bertie Blue

text:
Bertie:  Responses to your questions/comments:

Q: When you say rapidly warming are you suggesting the rate is unprecedented and is therefore only attributable to man made co2?

A: There have been rapid increases in temperatures in the distant past, but you imply by your question that if it happened naturally in the past, it can't be caused by man now.  That's not true.  There were wildfires before man walked the Earth.  That does not mean that people can't cause wildfires.  In fact, we know by many lines of evidence that man is causing the current warming.  One of the simpler lines of evidence is we know quite accurately how much fossil fuel we burn each year and, therefore, how much CO2 we put in the atmosphere (about 30~40 gigatons/year).  Since we have been studying greenhouse gases since the 1800's, we know how much warming the manmade greenhouse gases should cause and it matches what we see.

Q: Is it your contention there has not been a pause and co2 has risen in linear fashion to temp since the mid 1800s?.

A:  At the beginning of the industrial revolution, the smoke from fossil fuel burning caused more cooling than the CO2 caused warming and there was some cooling in the early part of the 20th century.  Re-industrialization after WW2 caused another dip, but by the 1970's, the warming effect took over and the warming has been steady since then, with natural fluctuations on a yearly basis.  But if you look at the average global temperature per decade, it has gone up steadily since the 1970's.  Remember that climate is the long-term average of weather (usually averaged over 30 years) and the 30-year temperature average has been steadily rising (though it's not "linear" and no one says it should be linear).  Note that the coal smoke that cools the Earth lasts in the atmosphere for a few weeks.  The CO2 that causes warming lasts in the atmosphere for hundreds to thousands of years.

Q: If you disagree with the 0.8c rise you disagree  with NASA/GISS this is their published estimate - please  focus.

A:  It was 0.8¬∫C a few years ago, but the global temperature has risen dramatically in the past 3 years (2014, 2015, and 2016 were all record years... I believe that is the first time there was 3 record years in a row).  2016 was about +1.2¬∫C above pre-industrial temperatures and February 2016 was +1.5¬∫C above pre-industrial.

Q: Why are you surprised ice is melting given it's been happening for milennia. Do you think it hasn't happened before?

A:  Why is the ice melting now?  The Sun's output is at low for the century.  The ice should be growing as we enter the next ice age period.  We know why there were ice ages and interglacial periods in the recent (last 800,000 years) past and why there were much warmer periods before that (due to orbital shifts and massive, long-term volcanic activity and continental shifts -- but that's not happening now).  The last time the Earth had 400ppm CO2 in the atmosphere, sea levels were 75 feet higher than today... that's where we are heading (and more) and it's manmade this time.

Q: 8000 bc a period known as the ‚Äúearly Holocene insolation maximum‚Äù (EHIM) had just such an event.

A: There were significant climate shifts as we transitioned to the inter-glacial period.  But civilization flourished under a remarkably stable climate in the past several thousand years.  It's getting unstable now and it won't be pretty.

The bottom line to most of your arguments is the fact that the climate has changed naturally in the past does not contradict in any way the fact that we know that man is causing the current warming.  There is overwhelming scientific evidence of manmade climate change which you choose to ignore and/or you believe that there is a vast conspiracy by scientists to fool everyone.  The nice thing about science is that it is true whether you believe it or not.

author: Bertie Blue

text:
Bertie:  What you seem to be missing is that CO2 is a very long-lived gas in the atmosphere.  So, when it comes to global warming, about the only thing that matters long-term is the CO2 concentration in the atmosphere, which has been steadily rising since the industrial revolution.  On top of the global warming "signal" is layered fluctuations from natural sources, (e.g., El Nino, La Nina, volcanoes, solar cycles, orbital cycles, etc.) and unnatural sources (manmade aerosols, e.g., coal smoke).

So, it doesn't matter that there was coal usage a long time ago.  The amount was small and it didn't effect the atmospheric CO2 concentration much (which was about 280ppm before the industrial revolution).

Why do you think coal smoke cooling the Earth defies basic reasoning?  Natural clouds have a high albedo (reflectivity) and reflect sunlight away from the Earth, which cools the Earth.  Coal smoke also has a high albedo and, from space, looks much like natural clouds.  Why then would it not reflect sunlight and cool the Earth?  Please explain.

As for "Rates of temp increase":  What's your point?  The temperature has generally been going up since the beginning of the 20th century, but in the first half of the 20th century, the fluctuation "noise" was larger than the global warming "signal".  It is certainly not surprising that you can find periods before 1970 where the RATE of temperature increase is similar to the RATE after 1970.  But the actual temperatures are higher in the 1970s-1990s than in the past.  So what's your point?  Just look at the graph of global temperatures:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temperature_record#/media/File:Global_Temperature_Anomaly.svg

I think almost everyone looking at the graph, including you, would agree that global average temperatures has been rising fairly steadily since the 1970s.  That's what matters.  If you want to argue that the temperature rise since the 1970s is not due to manmade emissions of greenhouse gases (and manmade land use changes), then please explain why the manmade GREENHOUSE gas emissions don't matter and explain what other forces are increasing global temperatures.  Thanks.

author: Andrew Wenman

text:
The existence of the greenhouse effect was first proposed and argued by Joseph Fourier in 1824.
Timeline: Climate Change | New Scientist
https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn9912-timeline-climate-change/
1957: US oceanographer Roger Revelle warns that humanity is conducting a ‚Äúlarge-scale geophysical experiment‚Äù on the planet by releasing greenhouse gases. Colleague David Keeling sets up first continuous monitoring of CO2 levels in the atmosphere. Keeling soon finds a regular year-on-year rise.
1970s: Series of studies by the US Department of Energy increases concerns about future global warming.

However despite rising concerns the monitoring of Co2 did not begin until the 1970‚Äôs.

The reason, it was at this time that the conflicts and controversies of the science community finally spilled over into the public arena.   

I was in my early 20‚Äôs at the time and remember well how the ‚ÄúVast Majority of scientists laughed at the idea of a greenhouse effect!!‚Äù, and did their damnedest over the years and decades that followed, to ridicule and make life hell for those who supported the idea. Today ‚Äúnone of them are laughing‚Äù and few if any have the guts to admit they ever doubted, or took part in attacking the theory; because they would have to hang their heads in shame, at having stifled years of serious research, and brought us all to the very edge of mammalian extinction. 

Ironic: Over most recent years and at the point when its original detractors are now a part of the 97% scientific consensus as to the reality of the greenhouse effect; they now find themselves in a similar position, of facing the skepticism and scorn of every ignoramus and dunce on the planet.

However as often is the case with reluctant converts their initial sense of disbelief has gone to the opposite extreme, of focusing purely on the greenhouse effect as to being the sole cause of global warming, to the exclusion of the most fundamental of causes of global overheating, which is the over production of heat itself. 

Certainly it is the ‚Äúthermal reflecting and insulating blanket of ‚Äútoxic-cancerous oil based hydrocarbons‚Äù and GHG‚Äôs, that are responsible for trapping the heat rising from the planet, ‚ÄúBut‚Äù the amounts of heat that were rising from the planet prior to deforestation for farming, and pre industrialization, has no comparison to the vast amounts of heat that are entering the rivers and oceans, and rising from the planet today.

text:
Why is it if I deny climate change I am living in denial. I like how you now say it will only take longer but it will happen. And I especially love how you cloak your socialist ideas. For someone who seems to have an understanding of capitalism and the free market enterprise system, you are either woefully ignorant or completely understand the socialist intent of your scheme.I believe it is the latter. 

For those who would wish to see another side of the debate read S. Fred Singer book Hot Talk Cold Science. S. 

Fred Singer is a distinguished astrophysicist who has taken a hard, scientific look at the evidence. In this book, Dr. Singer explores the inaccuracies in historical climate data, the limitations of attempting to model climate on computers, solar variability and its impact on climate, the effects of clouds, ocean currents, and sea levels on global climate, and factors that could mitigate any human impacts on world climate.

Singer‚Äôs masterful analysis decisively shows that the pessimistic, and often alarming, global warming scenarios depicted in the media have no scientific basis. In fact, he finds that many aspects of any global warming, such as a longer growing season for food and a reduced need to use fossil fuels for heating, would actually have a positive impact on the human race. Further, Singer notes how many proposed ‚Äúsolutions‚Äù to the global warming ‚Äúcrisis‚Äù (like ‚Äúcarbon‚Äù taxes) would have severe consequences for economically disadvantaged groups and nations.

Hot Talk, Cold Science is essential reading for anyone who wants to be fully informed about the global warming debate.

This debate is not settled has people like Dan Miller would like you to believe.

text:
Economic growth channeled into renewables will not be enough because growth promotes business competition, which results in development activities that maintain and accelerate deforestation patterns.  Reforestation has to be a strong, maybe the strongest, component of economic reforms.  This is because the CO2 that's already been released has to be reabsorbed and sequestered and only living, growing wood absorbs carbon and buries it underground as root growth.  Unless economic activities actively work to increase the land-area covered by thriving tree canopy throughout deforested areas, including cities and other human developments, CO2 will have nowhere to go and the deforested areas will absorb and release sunlight as heat that builds up due to CO2 blanketing.  

Reforestation is a double-edged sword to reduce CO2 climate effects because it both absorbs CO2 and buries it underground as root growth AND tree canopies shade the ground, buildings, and pavements from sunlight that gets absorbed and released into the air as heat and humidity, another greenhouse gas.  If trees are cut, their wood dies and decays into CO2 and the area they once shaded becomes a solar heater that absorbs sunlight and heats up.  So while stimulating economic reform with fee-and-dividend stimulus may help advance cleaner energies and technologies, it may also support continuing development and deforestation, which is currently not conscientious enough to fit buildings between trees instead of clearing land and replacing trees with buildings.
