text: Because we are not acting rationally in the face of the danger of climate change and it is useful to try to understand why.
author: Dan Miller

text: Dear Dan, Thanks for your reply, and also for your video. Regarding understanding why humans are not acting rationally in the face of climate change, first, I think your evolutionary explanation of our inaction is not needed: mass vaccination, for example, is a human response to a threat which seems to have all the criteria you note for climate change (unspecific, impersonal, pretty gradual, etc). Second I think humans ARE acting rationally in taking no action given what we see around us: namely, the vast vast majority getting on which capitalist consumption as usual, even while a few people warn of a terrible danger (and, worse, sometimes these two groups overlap). In these circumstances it is rational to assume the danger is false -- "if it REALLY was so bad, somebody'd have done something about it...". Anyway, I salute your activism and education work.
author: rapperfrgman

text:
Actually, before vaccinations, the country was traumatized by polio and other now-preventable diseases.  It was immediate, visible (paralyzed children in iron lungs), had historical precidence, simple causality, direct personal consequences (you or your kids could get it), and caused by an enemy (polio).  The public demanded action.  While most people today don't recall that, government policies were put in place to require the public to get vaccinations.  For example, you can't send your kids to school today without vaccinations.

Your other example ("if it REALLY was so bad, somebody'd have done something about it..."), is a description of the Bystander Effect that I discuss in my talk (the bus example).  While it is certainly a human trait, I would not describe it as rational.  It is NOT rational to assume the danger is false and in the case of climate change, we know -- rationally -- that the danger is not false.
author: Dan Miller

text:
Dear Dan, I certainly don't want to take¬† time away from your valuable work with merely philosophical questions --- climate change is far, far too urgent¬† -- but I can't help thinking that these appeals to (ir)rationality are red herrings. The concept of rationality is in any case underdefined, and, as David Hume showed, dissolves into incoherence when we try to say anything definite about it. There are concrete social and economic reasons why people are ignoring climate change -- reasons which we could do something about, whereas a genetic disposition to be risk-blind or irrational would seemingly be something we would be helpless against.

There's a beautful Mullah Nasruddin story which ends with the Mullah searching under the lamp post for his (far off) missing keys because "there's more light here". The appeal to irrationality seems to be the opposite of Nasruddin's lesson. We seek answers in the murky depths of rationality, to avoid FINDING the answers in the clear light of capitalism!

If the newspapers spoke in one voice about the horrific danger, public opinion would rapily shift.

text:
If you deny climate change then you certainly are living in denial.  It's not something that might happen in the future, it's happing now.  Global average surface temperatures have risen +1¬∫C since pre-industrial times (with a huge jump in the past 2 years).  The volume of Arctic sea ice in September has dropped about 70% in the past 30 years.  Change in growing seasons has already occurred.  While there may be a few "silver linings" in climate change, the vast majority of the impacts are negative and will overwhelm the few positive effects.

Al Gore never said that sea level rise would be inundating us by now.  But for your reference, the last time CO2 levels were as high as they are today (400 ppm), sea levels were about 75 feet higher than now.  It will take a long time for that much ice to melt, but that is the path we are on.  And I stand by the predictions that I made in the talk.

Having a provider of a product or service pay the entire cost of that product or service is a quite capitalist idea.  Allowing companies to shift their costs on to society, on the other hand, is one of the definitions of socialism.

Quoting one of the most famous climate deniers, Fred Singer -- featured in "Merchants of Doubt" -- won't help your case.

text:
+Dan Miller, the Holocene has had 10 warm periods, one every 1000 years or so, almost like clockwork. To declare this warm period as "man made" is ludicrous. We would've had a warm period now, with or without humans and their SUVs. The Little Ice Age was anomalously cold compared to other intra-warm periods. In fact, the last 3 warm periods show a strong downtrend (GISP2 ice core proxies). This suggests that the Holocene may be winding down.

And Ice Age? We already live in an Ice Age as defined by those 2 little white things persisting at the poles (Greenland and Antarctica). Climate changes on a far shorter time scale. Climate is changing right now and has for the last several billion years. At the start of the Holocene (end of the Younger Dryas), global average temperatures rose +5C in 50 years, far faster than our current "frightening" change. That Global Warming made civilization possible. Do you understand science well enough to explain why +5C of warming would make civilization possible?

Thirty million years ago, CO2 levels had been dropping for millions of years and reached about 800 ppm (twice today's levels). Plants freaked out and evolved C4 species to cope with the CO2 starvation. Let that fact sink in for a few weeks. Human production of extra CO2 is greening the Earth. Do you care about life on our planet? If you do, you'll promote more warming and more CO2. And bonus: warming helps remove CO2 from the oceans, keeping the pH at tolerable levels.

So Rod, think about what you are suggesting! We've known about CO2 for a long time. Are you really saying the Radiative Forcing Equation is a conspiracy?
From Wikipedia:
>>The existence of the greenhouse effect was argued for by Joseph Fourier in 1824. The argument and the evidence was further strengthened by Claude Pouillet in 1827 and 1838, and reasoned from experimental observations by John Tyndall in 1859.[12] The effect was more fully quantified by Svante Arrhenius in 1896.[13] However, the term "greenhouse" wasn't used to describe the effect by any of these scientists; the term was first used in this way by Nils Gustaf Ekholm in 1901.[14][15]  In 1917 Alexander Graham Bell wrote "[The unchecked burning of fossil fuels] would have a sort of greenhouse effect", and "The net result is the greenhouse becomes a sort of hot-house."[16][17] Bell went on to also advocate the use of alternate energy sources, such as solar energy.[18]<<
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greenhouse_effect#History
This short history shows that any 'conspiracy' Deniers believe in must span nearly 2 centuries. Just think about what they are suggesting! Some world-wide scientific conspiracy started just after the Napoleonic wars, and continued through WW1, WW2, the Cold War, the fall of the Soviet Union, the re-unification of Germany, etc.  Such a conspiracy surviving all these different world-changing political changes boggles the imagination. text:
(A) If global warming proceeds like most scientists have suggested, how will those who currently believe it is a hoax react?

(B) And if the world does nothing in terms of carbon taxes, carbon sequestration, geo-engineering, etc, and global warming does not proceed like most scientists have suggested, how will those who believe it is true then react?                           

In scenario B we could see a loss of trust in government and science, especially if it was proven to be an attempt to intentionally mislead the public. If it was proven to be a unintentional mistakn it seems probable that the public would understand. Science evolves over time and many people understand that. That being said, the public would be angry that they had to make so many sacrifices in terms of additional taxes and lifestyle changes.. but the world would go on. 
As a bi-product the health effects of transitioning from Coal and Fossil Fuels to Fusion, Solar, Wind, and Thorium Based Nuclear for transport and energy production would have benefits for public and environmental health, and potentially, even cheaper energy and transport costs. And cheaper transport and energy would just be the tip of the ice berg.

With scenario A we could see the end of human civilization, or a fall that takes hundreds of years to recover from. Some of the projections suggest we will see migrations caused by rising sea levels, drought, and natural disasters on a scale that would make the Syrian Refugee crisis look like a minor historical footnote. Now some have suggested it will be possible to grow crops in places previously too cold to support agriculture. However, if that land was gained at the expense of prime agricultural lands closer to the equator humanity is not coming out ahead. With the world population projected to peak at 10 billion, we need all of the land we can get for farming and good land, not half-melted border-line tundra.

Hey guys, there's a lot of hate in the comments right now, that's not going to solve anything. 

Benton Quest, 
Let's get our facts straight, 
One of the properties of CO2 is absorbing heat (more than other molecules), gasses with this property are refered to as 'greenhouse gasses' the more of it we have in our atmosphere, the more heat it holds on to from the sun. This is why Venus, the second planet, is so hot.

Also, the reason the term 'global warming' has been mostly replaced with 'climate change' is because scientists have noted over the years, that the rise in earth's temperature results in more fluctuations in weather, rather than just heating up. This is why the ice caps are melting, but the east coast experienced the worst snow it's ever gotten two years ago.


And, yes, our planet naturally has cycles of hotter and colder weather ex: the ice age vs. prehistoric eras. However, the recent heating the world is going through is off schedule. This is the fastest rapid and exponential increase in greenhouse gasses the world has ever been through-and is linked directly to the rise in CO2 emissions.

I understand where your questioning is coming from, and I'm glad you at least pay attention to what's going on with the 'climate crisis'. 

I hope this answered your question :)

text:
There are many ways to handle the "intermittency" issue.  For example, we can use "demand response" to lower electricity demand when renewable production is low (i.e., lower thermostats by 2¬∫, slow down charging of electric cars, etc.) and we can store renewable energy by simply pumping water uphill when energy is abundant and letting it flow downhill and turn a turbine when extra energy is needed.

Perhaps you weren't paying attention when I described Fee and Dividend. 100% of the money collected goes back to the public (the government doesn't get a dime) and because poor people generate less CO2 than wealthy people, they actually make more money from the dividend than they pay in higher prices.

Actually, you're wrong.  CO2 varies during the year because plants take it up as they grow in spring and summer and release it fall and winter.  While the Northern and Southern Hemispheres have opposite seasons, there is more land in the Northern Hemisphere, so it dominates the effect.
https://www3.epa.gov/climatechange/kids/documents/carbon-through-the-seasons.pdf

As the oceans warm due to manmade climate change, they lower their ability to absorb CO2 (though, so far, they have continued to absorb some of the manmade CO2 we are emitting, making the oceans more acidic).

And while a rise in global temperature causes an increase in atmospheric CO2, a rise in CO2 also causes a rise in global temperature.
http://www.skepticalscience.com/co2-lags-temperature.htm

You should check out SkepticalScience.com before posting more climate myths.

author: Abdul Akbar Saleem

text:
You're confusing CO2 flux with the lifetime of excess emissions.  Vast amounts of CO2 go in and out of the atmosphere but without man's influence the fluxes are balanced and the CO2 concentration of the atmosphere would be fairly constant (at 280 ppm).  But when man adds CO2 to the atmosphere some of it is quickly absorbed by the oceans (making the oceans more acidic) but the remainder stays in the atmosphere for hundreds to thousands of years.  Individual CO2 molecules may come and go, but the excess concentration (now about 407 ppm) remains.

Growing more trees is a good thing but it is not a long-term solution.  First, we are constantly spewing CO2 into the atmosphere so we would need to plant an area of trees equal the size of the UK every year just to keep up.  Second, those trees are still in the biosphere so when they die (due to drought, wild fire, bark beetle, or even natural causes) they release much of their CO2 back to the atmosphere.

There have been times in the distant past when natural processes caused CO2 levels to rise (over tens of thousands of years) and that lead to a global warming of 4 to 6¬∫C (where we are headed at the end of this century).  When that happened last time (55 million years ago) it caused a mass extinction event... something that we are at the beginning of now.

text:
Deforestation is a big problem that must be addressed.  Fee and Dividend does not address the problem but you could imagine putting a fee on deforestation.

Reforestation is a good thing but it is not a long-term solution to climate change since the carbon in the trees is still in the biosphere so when the trees die (due to drought, wildfire, bark beetle, or natural causes) most of the CO2 will be returned to the atmosphere.

It is possible to inject CO2 far underground (back where it came from) or inject it into to certain rock formations that will turn it into a solid (carbonate) in a decade or so.

You're correct that the economic stimulus caused by Fee and Dividend will have some negative environmental consequences.  More draconian policies might reduce emissions while driving down the economy, but I can't imagine those policies being adopted until things get much worse (though we might not need to wait long for that).
author: Dan Miller

text:
¬†@Dan Miller¬†
Living trees sequester carbon, energy, and water both above ground in their trunks and limbs as well as underground in their root systems.¬† Water vapor in the atmosphere also blankets heat so sequestering carbon alone doesn't prevent unsequestered sunlight from causing evaporation that blankets heat.¬† The living biosphere, through its trees and other water-based ecological forms channels energy through systems that slow dissipation of energy as heat and prevent evaporation and blanketing of heat by water.

There's nothing draconian about reforesting human developments, except to the extent that many people aesthetically prefer to remove trees from developed areas.¬† Aesthetic preference is not a good excuse for poor management of planetary energy, however.¬† Life evolved to thrive between the ground and the top of the canopy, for the most part.¬† The canopy is Earth's mechanism for absorbing sunlight and transfering the energy underground, where it sinks, fossilizes, and get gradually released as heat that keeps underground water warm enough to keep trees alive in winter.¬† We tend to think of underground temperatures as being due to primordial radioactivity stored within the core, but in all likelihood, sunken biomass plays a roll since the core would have cooled faster if it was isolated from any form of energy-input since the formation of the solar system.

text:
Fee and Dividend is the most transparent and fair carbon pricing policy.  There are no middlemen and everyone gets the same payment every month, so it's almost impossible to game the system.

We will still need a "WW2" level effort to fight climate change, but a fee on carbon will get us half-way there.  If you don't put a fee on carbon, you are allowing fossil fuel companies to pollute the atmosphere for free and you are forcing the rest of society to pay the costs.
author: Dan Miller

text:
A quick google search says global emissions are roughly 40,000 MMTCO2e per year. NASA estimates the total global absorption by vegetation at 2500 MMTCO2e per year. A best case CO2 absorption by forests is ~4 MTCO2e per acre; covering the entire arable surface of the earth (7.7 B acres) with such forests might absorb about 30,000 MMTCO2e. So yes, covering enough deserts with lush forests might theoretically take up enough of our pollution.

But that ignores the displacement of agricultural lands, finding enough water to irrigate several times the current arable acres, creating enough soil, setting aside mountainous areas and areas for wild species, and of course the cost of such afforestation. With renewables getting cheaper than fossil fuels and already far cheaper than the total costs of fossil fuels, clean energy and improved energy efficiencies are clearly the cheapest and fastest path to cleaning up the atmosphere. IMHO we must now accelerate the energy transition by helping the free market see the real costs of fossil fuels.
author: Eric Strid

text:
Why do climate scientists like Dan Miller and James Hansen, and even Secretary of Everything George Schulz, think that we'll buy less fossil fuels by taxing those fuels and then refunding the same tax back to us? Anyone with an average fuel usage would get a dividend check equal to the tax they paid. It's like increasing the fee for a speeding ticket and refunding the increased fee. How will that change any behaviors? Anyone with less-than-average fuel usage would actually get a lower cost of fossil fuels. No wonder Big Oil favors this system for carbon pricing. Wake up, CCL!
A far better system, also revenue-neutral, punishes dirty infrastructure investment with a fee and rewards low-emission infrastructure with a rebate. Such feebates allow prices much higher than $30/MTCO2e, which is roughly where leakage sets in, and don't punish people or businesses for using the infrastructure currently available to them. See Rocky Mountain Institute on vehicle feebates.

text:
Dan, I follow your model for trying to suppress usage of polluting fossil fuels; however the issue can be simplified and pro-actively address the volume of pollution.

If you believe the volume of CO2 (110 Million tonnes per day, I'm told) going into the atmosphere and the longevity of this in the atmosphere; it is highly unlikely the planet will achieve the less than 2C temperature rise. Zero Carbon is not going to happen for many decades, if at all.

However we could start removing atmospheric CO2 albeit at very small volumes, initially. Most commentators are fixed on the sudden (& un-achievable) removal of fossil fuels when what the entire planet needs to understand and act on is including the cost of pollution into the price of the product. For example: Factor in an estimate of removing the pollution from burning 1 litre of petrol in your car (say $30) and petrol is no longer cheap. Do the same for coal used in a power station and coal becomes hugely expensive; more so than Nuclear power which has no global warming attributes.

Our so-called energy policies have been founded on the (misunderstood) apparently low cost of fossil fuels. Which means these policies are fundamentally flawed because you cannot compare use of fossil fuels with no pollution cost, with nuclear or renewables; they are not even apples and oranges, more like a swede and a strawberry!

But sadly that is what economists and policy makers have been doing and continue to do....

The problem is one of education and policy. Economists must stop avoiding pollution costs and policy-makers need to introduce legislation that requires all fossil fuel suppliers and large polluting industries to factor in the actual cost of pollution remediation and then undertake said remediation.

If you work for an oil & gas company you might want to alert senior managers to the possibility of diversifying into pollution remediation so that your reserves can be monetized without damaging the planet; or go out of business in the next couple of decades.

All too expensive you say. Indeed and that is the real cost of using fossil fuels that we have avoided so far.

We cannot avoid them much longer.

The good news about properly understanding the cost of pollution and factoring it into energy sources is that a parallel industry; let's call it the fossil-fuel sewerage business is required in order to undertake pollution remediation. This requires capital, technology and staff, all of which is good for global economic growth. Gradually build up remediation capacity; a good place could be Saudi Arabia using solar power to run large scale atmospheric CO2 removal.

Depending on the volume & rate of remediation we may be able to continue using fossil fuels without pushing the mean global temperature beyond a critical limit.

So there you are; a simple solution to fossil fuel derived global warming using basic economics and the equivalent of the sewerage industry that became established in the 19th Century when we realised that defecating in our own back yard wasn't very smart.

See Facebook Group: Environmental Energy

text: Eric:  You might have been right of there were no alternatives to using fossil fuels.  But there are.  So putting a rising fee on the bad thing (fossil fuels) encourages people to seek out good alternatives (renewables) and also encourages them to use less through energy efficiency.  Renewable energy is currently about the same cost as fossil energy even though fossil energy gets a huge subsidy since it is allowed to pollute the atmosphere for free.  A carbon fee is a way to correct this "market failure" and when that happens, renewables will be much cheaper than fossil fuels and power companies and everyone else will buy renewable energy instead of fossil energy.
author: Dan Miller

text:
The cost trajectories of renewables will continue to push lower because of production experience curves--BNEF's latest data shows wind on a 19% rate, PV on a 24% rate, and battery costs plummeting. This will continue (even without technology breakthroughs) with little effect from an emissions price, because the practical maximum carbon fee (~30 cents/gallon or $30/MTCO2e) is way lower than the fuel price volatility (we'd need $1.50/gallon just to get back to gasoline prices two years ago, which were way too low to stop us from driving). 
I strongly agree that we have market failures, but we must be realistic about solutions. Besides $30/MTCO2e being far too low a price signal and far less than the actual social costs of $100-500/MTCO2e, consumers count only 2-3 years of operating costs when buying a vehicle or appliance. A new vehicle or house or appliance will consume fossil fuels throughout its useful life, and thus the decision point with by the most leverage is the purchase of new infrastructure. At that point the sticker should list the actual social cost of the purchase decision (the social costs for the full lifetime of the product), and the fee or rebate necessary for a strong price signal would be much less than that social cost. 
A fee on emissions (assuming we don't refund it back to everyone) can affect behaviors like driving less or slower or carpooling to save fuel, but better behaviors with dirty infrastructure will get us only ~20% of the way to zero emissions. A proven business adage is, "You can't save your way back to health--you must innovate."
author: Eric Strid

text:
Eric:  The plan for Fee and Dividend is to start at $10/ton and increase it by $10/ton every year for at least 10 years.  This gets you to $100/ton in 10 years.  Since you dividend out all the money collected, most people make money on the deal and the public will support a $100/ton fee and beyond.  If you don't return the money to the public, you are correct that you are probably limited to $30/ton (at least for now).

The other nice feature of a rising carbon fee is that everyone knows it will be $100/ton in 10 years so power plant developers, companies, and individuals start planning right away for the higher fee.  This will spur investment, innovation, and deployment of low-carbon technologies.
author: Dan Miller

text:
OK, Congress suddenly starts cooperating and passes a price on carbon in 2017. By 2027 we‚Äôd have a $100/MTCO2e fee on emissions or about a dollar per gallon of gasoline; thus gasoline would still be cheaper than in 2014. (Global markets will probably still be awash in oil, due to transportation electrification.) When buying a new car, consumers will see gas as cheaper than when he/she afforded it in 2014. Where is the incentive to drive less than they did in 2014, and where is the incentive to buy a more efficient car?

‚Äú‚Ä¶power plant developers, companies, and individuals start planning right away for the higher fee.‚Äù They will plan for oil prices being a little higher, but still lower than in 2104. Why would they change anything re oil consumption? If it made no sense to change at $4/gallon, then it makes even less sense to change at $3.50. 

Worse than way too low a price signal and way too late, returning the money to the public negates most of the incentive to change. An average consumer will be pissed to find that oil companies simply passed the fee onto consumers and utilities simply passed the fee onto ratepayers, etc. Then he‚Äôll be relieved that he gets it all back, but Republicans will be pissed because all it did was redistribute income with a lot of government overhead. Where are the implementations of fee and dividend systems that demonstrate emission reductions?

And way before we got to $100/ton, companies would be demanding border carbon adjustments on exports and imports to keep costs fair. That would be a very complex, challenging, and expensive system.

In the vehicle feebate scenario, a new vehicle within a class is charged a fee if it is lower efficiency than the target efficiency or receive a rebate if it is higher than the target. Typical auto lifetime is 150,000 miles, so a 20 mpg car will use 7500 gallons of fuel. At $100/ton and 22 lb/gal, the lifetime social cost of emissions is $7500. Even a fraction of that $7500 would slow down sales significantly and make a nice rebate for a zero-emission vehicle. Thus the fees are dividended directly to subsidizing more efficient infrastructure. Leakage can be controlled by the state of vehicle registration. Vehicle feebates have been very successful in France and the province of Ontario.
author: Eric Strid

text: Eric: The carbon fee can keep climbing after 10 years (people will probably be sufficiently worried about climate change by then).  There will be technologies available that can eliminate CO2 for less than the carbon fee, so why would a power plant operator pay more than they need to?  When fossil fuels get more expensive, renewables will be even more competitive than they are now (and they are cost competitive with fossil fuels now and getting cheaper all the time).  A boarder duty is a key element of Fee and Dividend.  It "encourages" other countries to also put a price on carbon.  You can view the economic analysis of Fee and Dividend at: http://citizensclimatelobby.org/remi-report/
author: Dan Miller

text:
The Fee and Dividend fee rises to $100/ton over ten years... higher than other carbon policies.  Unless you give the money back to the public, it won't be politically possible to get the fee that high (or higher).  A carbon fee that rises to $100/ton will drive investment, innovation, and deployment of clean energy solutions.

The carbon fee makes fossil fuels more expensive and renewables even more competitive.  There is no reason for people to keep buying fossil fuels when alternatives are cheaper.  Wouldn't you rather spend your dividend on other things besides expensive dirty energy?
author: Dan Miller

text:
To reiterate, besides $100/ton on current emissions not being high enough to accomplish anything but an uproar over imports and exports, dividending it out to everyone who paid it will dilute the impact to everyone except those who've already fixed their footprint.

If you haven't upset anyone, then you haven't changed anything. If Big Oil favors your carbon pricing plan, then it's probably ineffective. Again, what jurisdiction has implemented a fee-and-dividend system?

By contrast, fees on lifetime emissions have demonstrated efficacy in bringing the correct price signal to the market, and the fee could correspond to well over $100/ton.
author: Eric Strid

text:
Ironically, the Biggest Oil Rockefeller climate change scam is seductively distracting people from the real facts.

Global Warming made civilization possible 12,000 years ago. You, in Sweden, should be more critically aware of the implications of this. Sweden used to be buried under a mountain of ice. But we're still in an Ice Age as long as those 2 little white things persist at the poles.

Thirty million years ago, CO2 levels plummeted down to 800 ppm (twice today's levels), and plants freaked out, evolving C4 species to cope with the CO2 starvation. Think about that fact long and hard and then understand the pseudo-science and anti-science being promoted by the "climate change" Warming Alarmists.

Alarm is good only when it's true. Since we live in an ongoing Ice Age with the Holocene interglacial overdue to end (Ref: W.S. Broecker, 1998), warming is the solution!

And since human production of extra CO2 is greening the Earth, those who truly care about our planet should be applauding our CO2 increases. Oceans? Warming forces CO2 out. Sea level rise? Moving is far easier than surviving 90,000 years without summer (glacial period).

Check your luck. Your missing a big chunk through willful ignorance. Study the science more carefully. See how you're being lied to.
author: Rod Martin, Jr.

text: As Benjamin Franklin said "We must all hang together, or most assuredly we shall all hang separately."  I don't think your individual approach will work.  The good news is that Fee and Dividend does not use carbon credits swaps or other such nonsense.  It's simple, transparent, and fair.  Also keep in mind that a similar system is in place in Alaska (the Alaska Permanent Fund) and it works well there and almost everyone loves it.  I'm not saying that everything will be roses if we implement Fee and Dividend, but it will help us avoid some of the really bad impacts that would make your individual efforts futile.

text:
+Dan Miller:  You and I got into a vigorous debate about global warming about 4 years ago in a comment thread on TED.com. I'm a bit nervous to confront you with quotes from that discussion, because I myself said some things then that I'm embarrassed about now. (For what it's worth, I was 21.) However, at the time, you said, "extreme events (3-sigma) are now happening 25 to 50 times more often than just 50 years ago." I thought that was clearly wrong, so I asked you if you stood by it after giving it some thought, and you said you did, and then elaborated: "When Extremely Hot Days are happening over 10% of the land area instead of 0.2% of the land area, they are happening 50 times more often in individual places... which is what matters."

Now, I'm happy to see that you made no reference in this TEDx talk to "extreme events," heat waves, or anything else becoming 25 to 50 times more frequent over the past several decades. In fact, you didn't mention any documented increase in extreme weather of any kind. Surely, if you still stood by the claim that any kind of extreme weather has become 25 to 50 times more frequent, in any meaningful sense, you would have included it in your talk. After all, it's an incredibly alarming claim. So, did you leave it out because you've lost confidence in it? Have you thought about why, 4 years ago, you were so confused about this?

text: The warming you refer to is in the air.  However, evaporation pulls latent heat from the environment (sea water, fresh water lakes, and land) resulting in a cooling effect.  Convection negates some of this water vapor "add" as you call it.   Increased cloud formation then negates more of this add.  The question is: by how much?  The water vapor feedback can also be a "minus" instead of an add when the entire hydrological cycle is considered.  Adding more atmospheric water vapor does not create more heat, just moves it into the atmosphere. Your assertion that warming is a given with more atmospheric water vapor is fundamentally wrong.  You have to consider its cooling effect from removal of latent heat.

text:
+Solving Tornadoes the CO2 molecule has dozens of resonances in the near and far infrared, as does the water molecule. They are 'mechanical' resonances, due to the very many modes of virbration of the molecules - both water and carbon dioxide being made up of a central atom with two outriders, either in a linear non-polar molecule (CO2), or a 'bent' and assymetric (and polar) molecule (H2O). These molecules absorb infrared energy at many frequencies and then reemit it. Water molcules also have dozens of resonances in the same general region of the spectrum, but these rarely exactly coincide precisely with CO2 absorption/emmision lines. You might think at first these two processes would not interact very much, only where the molecules had the same resonance frequency. However, all of these molecules are moving, at considerable speed, over a wide range of speeds, and the effect of this, due to the doppler effect, is that from the point of view of a receiving molecule, the emission can appear to the receiving molecule to be at the right frequency to be absorbed, depending on its relative motion - another way to look at this is to view it as the the spectral lines being broadened, and the degree of broadening depends on the speeds of the molecules, and hence on the temperature. This boadening is easily measured. This behaviour is what makes the calculation of the degree of interaction of the two gases very complicated - but experimentally, it's much easier to demonstrate and measure, and the degree of interaction for further calculation is approximated at each temperature. There's no end of evidence this happens, going back a hundred years.
You don't know any science. That is clear.
author: Dick Hamilton

text: +Dick Hamilton It just so happens I'm an expert on this very subject.  I am an atmospheric physicist.  Everything you say is true.  But there is no drama.  The drama is in your imagination.  The magnitude of thermal impact from CO2 is neither significant or necessarily warming.  You've been bamboozled with irrelevant details that look dramatic to an amateur but that don't necessarily even produce a warming effect.
author: Solving Tornadoes

text:
+Solving Tornadoes you are no atmospheric scientist. That is clear. It is no trouble at all to demonstrate that incoming radiation is partially absorbed by the atmosphere and reemitted in all directions, so that some then leaves the atmosphere, reemitted to space. The remainder travels on through the atmosphere being absorbed and reemitted, mostly elastically (though there is some direct heating), some always backscattered, until it reaches the surface. The surface warms, and radiates a very broad range of wavelengths upwards. It is the infrared component of this radiation that interacts with the carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, and here, backscatter occurs in just the same way as before. But in this case, the backscatter has a significant component towards the earth, i.e. the CO2 and interacting H20 constitute an impedance to heat leaving the atmosphere for space. This is the greenhouse effect, and it is very easily demonstrated. It is no trouble to demonstate and measure if you have the right facilities, and it is easy to show that a tank of air above an absorbing base, with added CO2, absorbs a certain proportion of downwards incident radiation (characterised by the increase in temperature of the gas in the tank), that changing the CO2 for water vapour absorbs a different amount, producing a different temperature, and that in the presence of both gases, the temperature increases by more than the sum of the separate effects of the two. This demonstrates the interaction between the two kinds of molecules. It is easy to show. 
You are not an expert in anything. I would call you something else.

author: Dick Hamilton

text: +Dick Hamilton, there's some good news possibilities on that.  More recent information is out there on things like permaculture water harvesting/storage methods,  range fertilization and mob grazing methods that restore damaged grasslands, and some old and new carbon sequestration methods. See vids about Polyface Farms, for instance.  Besides new high-tech chemical methods of pulling CO2 out of the air, there's a famous old and possibly accidental method.  Studies on terra preta soils in Amazonia show proof of how long biochar might last in soils, essentially entombing carbon from normal decomposition that would otherwise have  put it back in the atmospheric pool.  Some of the larger industrial methods of creating it also pull off very useful energy from burning the flue gases generated in  a low oxygen furnace.  Handled correctly, this char can also be hugely beneficial on water purification, on improving soil texture and water infiltration, and soil fertility.  It's not a magic pill, but helpful as part of an entire developing portfolio of sequestration methods.

Keep in mind, I'm with you on the need to tax carbon as a way to tackle AGW ('cause, you know, somewhere along the line someone reading this will call me a denier.) I am interested in this subject so I pulled the following to share:


When Hansen cited the 2010 Russian heatwave as evidence of global warming, he failed to mention that the NOAA reported that the Russian heatwave of 2010 was due to natural variability in an area which has a climatological vulnerability to heat waves, such as those of 1960, 1972 and 1988.

The heat wave was centered in Western Russia, but Hansen failed to mention the cooler-than-normal temperatures experienced in Siberia. He also failed to mention the 2010 peer-reviewed published paper by Dole et al. in which they concluded:

‚ÄúJuly surface temperatures for the region impacted by the 2010 Russian heat wave show no significant warming trend over the prior 130-year period from 1880-2009.‚Äù

And:

‚ÄúNo significant difference exists between July temperatures over western Russia averaged for the last 65 years (1945-2009) versus the prior 65 years (1880-1944).‚Äù

I have read one survey (I will supply the link) of US scientists which reports that of all scientists (biosciences, physics, astronomy etc.) polled, nearly 33% call climate science less trustworthy than their own field. That is amazing to me as it signifies that there is good reason to proceed conservatively in addressing ACW. I would rather that the conversation be honest and recognize the potential faults and problems with the existing climate science. Radicals (not you) have polluted sensible conversation as much as any denier with a political agenda. You are now saying there are different points of view about a single heatwave and say that it was more extreme than thought. That's NOT what you said in your presentation. You were unequivocal.
author: Simon Tschinkel

text:
+Simon Tschinkel I think Dr. Hopps wears his denier badge proudly.¬†


I'll say a few things...
1.  There is no proof in science, only in mathematics.  We understand climate change about as well as we understand gravity.  Not the details like where the next storm will hit, but we know that adding CO2 to the atmosphere by burning fossil fuels will raise global temperatures, raise sea levels, etc.  Science has known this since the 1800's.  To be more specific, every major scientific academy in the world -- without exception -- says global warming is real, is mostly caused by humans, and requires urgent action:
http://nationalacademies.org/onpi/06072005.pdf



2.  Climate change is a one-way street.  Whatever temperature we hit when we finally stop emitting greenhouse gases (GHGs) is the temperature we will be stuck with for the next 1000 years.  So if we follow your advice and climate change turns out to be a big problem like most scientists say, then all future generations are screwed.


3.  I do believe that most climate scientists are wrong to some degree.  It turns out that they are probably playing down the risks of climate change and the urgency of the need to lower GHGs.  After all, they're human and they know people don't want to hear bad news.  If you want to argue that climate change won't be as bad as most scientists say, then you must also accept that it could be worse than they say.  For a number of reasons, the chances of the later is higher than the former.


4.  I do believe that the Russian heatwave was directly linked to global warming for the reasons I stated (Hansen's paper).  But I acknowledge that in this particular case, there are still different points of view in the scientific community.  But look at it another way, we have raised global temperature by 0.8¬∫C already so how could the Russian heatwave have NOT been effected by global warming?
author: Dan Miller

text:
+Dan Miller You make the mistake of addressing me as if I need to be convinced ACW is real when this is not why I am conversing with you (why then add point #1?).¬†


Point #2 is you seem like a guy who appreciates economics. There is the science of ACW and then there are the economics of dealing with it and it is the economics which I feel way too many people are illiterate. To think that we have any clue as to what life will be like on earth in 1000 years, given the pace of technolocial and biological change we are likely to experience (see Kurzweil's "Singularity") is a huge leap of faith. I will not sacrifice my hypothetical $1 now for a discounted payoff in the future. My hypothetical $1 would have to yield >$1 in the future for it to make sense. Because I am a layman on this subject, others can explain it much better than I can and I'm sure you can source this quite easily.¬†


Point #4 demonstrates poor logic. To illustrate why it is so faulty imagine I said this: I shat in the ocean and thereby polluted it. Subsequently, there was a bad storm and the health authorities closed the beach due to high levels of coliform bacteria. Therefore the closing of the beach must have been affected by my shitting in the surf.
author: Simon Tschinkel

text:
+Simon Tschinkel Your economic approach is invalid.  If you want to chose between eating one pizza now vs. eating two next week, that's fine.  But you want to chose to eat one pizza now and have our children eat no pizzas in the future.  Borrowing from our children is a moral issue, not an economic one.  But even from a pure economic analysis, it is much, much cheaper to address climate change now rather than pay for future impacts (see Sir Nicholas Stern, the IEA, World Bank, etc.).


Your poop in the ocean analogy implies that the impacts of the +0.8C warming is just "a drop in the ocean".  That's not true.  The Earth's current "energy imbalance" (energy in minus energy out) which is driving global warming is about 0.6 watt/m^2 which is equivalent to having 400,000 Hiroshima atomic bombs going off each and every day.  That's not a drop in the ocean.  And that doesn't even include the energy that already went in to warming the Earth by 0.8C.  That's just the energy left to warm the Earth further based on our past emissions.


It seems that your basic argument is that there is uncertainty about climate change so we should wait until we are more certain before taking dramatic action that may impact the economy.  Yes, there is some uncertainty, but that is a reason for action, not inaction.  If an airplane mechanic says there is a 50% chance that the plane's engine oil seals are not in place properly, would you put your children on that flight?  Of course not, even though there is considerable uncertainty that the plane will crash.  The probability that business-as-usual emissions will lead to catastrophic climate change is much more than 50% (but it's not 100%).  There is no moral reason why we should subject our children (and all future generations) to the risks of our inaction.
author: Dan Miller

text:
+Dan Miller You are unfamiliar with the economic and valid criticisms by credentialed folks of the Stern Review. Any discussion of addressing ACW is incomplete without an understanding of what kind of impacts aggressive carbon reduction policies will have on human development and the best way a hypothetical $1 should be spent now vs. in the future. We agree about one thing which is that there is a moral responsibility. Many of the calls for the kind of carbon reduction levels needed to have even a projected modest payoff in 100 years would end up keeping people in poverty and reduce advancements in developing societies.


But we have digressed far from my original criticism of your comment linking a heatwave with climate change. I hope you'll keep this in mind in the future. Thanks for a civil and honest discussion.

author: Dan Miller

text: +Serebra Sana There are different types of geoengineering.  Solar Radiation Management (e.g., putting smoke in the atmosphere to block sunlight) is cheap but has bad side effects and doesn't solve the underlying problem.  Carbon Removal uses systems to suck CO2 out of the atmosphere and put it back underground where it came from.  This has far fewer side effects and solves the underlying problem of too much CO2 in the atmosphere, but it is enormously expensive.  It's far cheaper to stop using fossil fuels and switch to renewable energy.

text:
+er ha Since when do religions rely on consensus???  Science is a process for coming up with theories (also known as "laws"), such as the theory of gravity, that helps us understand our world.  Such useful theories are adopted by most scientists in a particular field and you can then say there is consensus about that theory.  The theories about climate change, greenhouse gases, etc. have been found to be useful by the scientific community and they work in helping us understand our world and where we are headed if we continue to emit greenhouse gases.


You are quite confused about the scientific process if you think that the fact that most scientists agree about AGW means that AGW is a religion.  That would mean that gravity, electromechanics, and astrophysics are all religions!  That, of course, is nonsense.

Gravity or gravitation is a natural phenomenon by which all things attract one another including stars, planets, galaxies and even light and sub-atomic particles. Gravity is responsible for the formation of the universe (e.g. creating spheres of hydrogen, igniting them under pressure to form stars and grouping them in to galaxies). Gravity is a cause of time dilation (time lapses more slowly in strong gravitation). Without gravity, the universe would be without thermal energy and composed only of equally spaced particles. On Earth, gravity gives weight to physical objects and causes the tides. Gravity has an infinite range, and it cannot be absorbed, transformed, or shielded against.
This will be an elementary example, however, it will serve the purpose.
If things mysteriously started ¬†floating up to the sky, is there any scientist that would not pause and consider , and probably declare questionable, Newton's theory of gravity? author: er ha

text:
+er ha You don't know how science works because you claim that gravity "has been proven by the scientific method".  It has not.  In fact, nothing is "proven" by the scientific method.  In science, "theory" is the highest state of knowledge about something and it is also called a "law", i.e., "The Theory of Gravity" and "The Law of Gravity".  Like climate change, there is still much that we do not know about gravity.  But like gravity, we know enough about climate change to make useful predictions about the future.


Your claims that "the models are wrong" are incorrect, unless you are implying that scientists are being conservative and things are likely to be worse than they have said (for example, Arctic sea ice has melted much faster than original IPCC predictions).
http://skepticalscience.com/climate-models.htm



If you want to continue to claim that "climate models are wrong", please provide peer-reviewed scientific articles that support your claim.  Articles from denier sites don't count.  Ad hominem attacks also don't count.


Of course, models are just one part of climate science.  We can look at the past and see what happened and we can also observe what is happening now.  For example, the past 12 months have been the warmest since temperature records began and 2015 is on track to be the warmest year by a margin of an incredible 0.1¬∫C!  I find it amazing that people still claim that climate change isn't happening while we are in the middle of it with record temperatures being reached every few years.

author: Dan Miller

text:
+Mike G 
"The amount of carbon in the atmosphere is minimal, and the amount of carbon that we contribute as percentage of this is minimal."


400ppm may not seem like much to you, but you need to take into account the effect that has, in terms of retaining infra-red solar radiation. The atmospheric concentration of CO2, in pre-industrial times was about 260ppm. That's a significant increase!


Photosynthesis absorbs about 100 billion tonnes of carbon, from the atmosphere, per year. Prior to the industrial revolution, this absorption was balanced, over the long term, by the carbon emitted by respiration, volcanism etc. Since the industrial revolution, we humans have tipped the balance, so that more carbon is removed from fossil fuels (which took a very long time to form) and are being added to the atmosphere.


Do you dispute that CO2 is a greenhouse has? Please help me understand why so many people are in denial of anthropogenic climate change.

author: Dan Miller

text: +Dan Miller Correct me if i am wrong but isn't a "Fee and Dividend policy" leaving the inflation adjustment part to Congress?!  In other words over time it will become less progressive and it will be just a backdoor way to introduce regressive taxation like the AMT.  I agree with including externalities into the system but not by taxing consumption.  The fossil fuel industry is engaging in what David Ricardo described as "rent seeking" activity.  I would fix that and remove the subsidies, open up the energy market to alternatives and force real competition by forcing  producers to switch to 100% wind and solar over time.  All of this could be achieved by taxing rent seeking and wealth hoarding as opposed to the productive economy.
author: szatmar666

text: +szatmar666 With Fee and Dividend (F&D), there is no inflation adjustment.  There is a rising fee on the CO2 content of fossil fuels, starting at $10/ton and going up $10/ton every year for ten years (and maybe more).  The fee is meant to account for the external costs and the collected fees are returned to every legal resident.  As the carbon fee rises, fossil fuels become less competitive and renewables become more competitive.  As a separate action, subsidies for fossil fuels should be eliminated.

Not only does NASA and NOAA say this, but so does the relevant authorities in Japan and the UK.  Are those countries also part of the conspiracy?


As for your trope that name of the issue was changed from global warming to climate change, that's just a denier talking point and it's not true.  As I point out in the talk, the first "global warming" paper was written in 1896.  But the first "modern" paper was written by Gilbert Plass in 1956 and it was called "The Carbon Dioxide Theory of Climatic Change" and it formed the basis for the Bell Science Hour clip that I showed in the talk. And you may recall that the UN group, formed in 1988, is called the International Panel on Climate Change and not the Internal Panel on Global Warming.  You can see more here:

text:
¬†@Bryan Seigneur¬†
There are much fairer alternatives to just distributing it equally. For example, make percent deductions from other taxes. If the new carbon tax constituted, for example, 30% of all other taxes, make people pay 30% less on them. This way, if someone is an average polluter, he will pay as much as before, if someone is living ecologically, he will make more money and if someone is polluting a lot, he will lose it. Moreover, the tax return will be felt by everyone in an equal fashion. Unlike the scenario in which a hobo and an university professor get an equal return: the first one will not even think about working when he recieves so much money for free (he cannot afford driving anyway), while the second will not feel the return but will certainly feel the costs.

This is supposed to stop pollution, and not make a socialist distribution of income under the disguise of preventing pollution.
author: MegaMementoMori

text: ¬†@MegaMementoMori¬† Reducing taxes is not the fairest way to distribute the collected carbon fees.  Poor people who don't pay any or much taxes will be hurt the most since they will be stuck with higher prices but won't get anything back.  Giving the money back equally to everyone is the fairest approach.  People who pollute the most pay the most.  The poor pollute less than the wealthy so they actually make more money on the dividend than they pay in higher prices.  Everyone still has an incentive to use less fossil fuels.
author: Dan Miller

text:
¬†@Dan Miller¬†
(Once again, the fact of a participant of TED replying to me is awesome! Thanks!)

I understand your point, where a person's expenses will inevitably rise, and if somebody would not pay much (or in countries with a large tax-free income bracket - at all) in taxes, he would be on the losing side no matter how he saves energy. You convinced me that my idea went too far.

But I am afraid that in the original concept the rich and the upper middle class will - in total - lose more no matter if they live energy - efficiently or not. For example, the creation and distribution of a normal car probably uses about as much oil as the creation and distribution of a Lamborghini. But I doubt if the costs of these cars would rise equally, if there would be a trend in the increase of car prices, they will rise a similar %, not total value - but the purchasers of these cars will receive back the same total amount and not %.

So, a university professor will not even feel the amount given back, while a McDonald's worker will probably contemplate quitting his job, which would in turn drive McDonald wages - and prices - up, ending up in a classical inflation scenario.

Again, I think that Your core idea is brilliant, however the idea of giving everybody equally might lead to socialist results as a side effect, and tweaking the formula a bit (not as much as making it only % tax deductions, but not indiscriminate handouts either) could keep the benifits while limiting the side effects.

text: While we need to reforest the planet, invest in cleantech R&D, and do similar things, they won't be enough as long as we let fossil fuels pollute the atmosphere for free. ¬†You can think of that as an enormous subsidy for fossil fuels so the clean technologies cannot compete on a level playing field. ¬†As far as climate change is concerned, the only thing that matters is total cumulative global emissions, so it's not enough to only increase clean energy production. ¬†We need to also rapidly decrease dirty energy production. ¬†The best way to do that is to make it more expensive.
author: Dan Miller

text: ¬†@Dan Miller¬† ... and Fee & Dividend and Border fees on CO2, no matter how effective, won't prevent at least another 0.6 C temperature rise.¬† Removing CO2 from the atmosphere can do that, at least in part, which is why a massive effort to regenerate landscapes with more biomass and soil carbon in the form of topsoil is necessary.¬† This will also aid in halting desertification and biodiversity loss/extinction, which are threatening us as well.¬† Other important benefits include the ability to increase soil moisture, and generate albedo producing clouds and much needed raindrops through nucleation from trees, both of which are cooling effects.¬† Maybe this critical and necessary work can be integrated and pad for somehow within the Fee & Dividend and CO2 Tariff mechanisms.
author: Glenn Gall

text:
¬†@Dan Miller¬†¬†Fee & Dividend sounds too good to be true, and I fear it is. Developing and scaling up clean-energy technology will require the use of fossil fuels (that will be increasingly expensive because of both depletion and Fee & Dividend). It's hard to see how CO2 emissions can be reduced by 52% while simultaneously growing GDP. That's leaving aside the continuing dependence of renewable energy sources on fossil fuels for construction and maintenance.¬†

The future is one of less energy and negative growth, and presumably the end of growth-dependent capitalism. There may be a role for some form of¬†Fee & Dividend, but it cannot be simply grafted onto BAU.
author: klondike444

text:
¬†@klondike444¬†¬†You should remember that the "external" costs of fossil fuels are real and must be paid by you, me, and the rest of society. ¬†This means that fossil fuels are not as cheap as they appear and our economy is running inefficiently. ¬†By putting a price on fossil fuels, we will use fossil fuels and renewable energy more efficiently and our economy will run more efficiently. ¬†Most European nations have much higher taxes on fossil fuels and their carbon footprint is about half of ours in the U.S., even though most of them have a very high standard of living.

So you can view Fee and Dividend as helping to correct what Sir Nicholas Stern calls "the biggest market failure in history".
author: Climate Chat Club

text:
¬†@Dan Miller¬†¬†Fossil fuels were cheap but are becoming more expensive - hence the ongoing economic problems. It is a mistake to think in terms of money rather than energy return on investment (EROI). Using energy more efficiently means you run into the Jevons Paradox, and are likely to use more of it, and more of other depleting resources, increasing the impact on the environment overall. That applies to all economies, and the US is just one of the major players.

Again, renewable energy sources turn out to need a large fossil fuel input, and mostly produce electricity, but industrial civilization is very dependent on liquid fuels: it will take an enormous investment of energy, including fossil fuels, and other resources to change that situation. Conventional (cheap) oil peaked in 2005, fracking will soon start to peter out, and the oil exported by producing nations is falling each year, faster than conventional output.

Energy availability is going to fall. Current input from renewables, not counting hydroelectric, is tiny. Climate change is not going to wait for us to gradually modify our behavior via financial policies. I do not think you have the solution to our self-created crisis.

http://ourfiniteworld.com/2014/11/18/eight-pitfalls-in-evaluating-green-energy-solutions/
http://www.truth-out.org/news/item/27392-abundant-clean-renewables-think-again
http://ourfiniteworld.com/2014/01/21/ten-reasons-intermittent-renewables-wind-and-solar-pv-are-a-problem/
author: klondike444

text:
¬†@klondike444¬†¬†EROI does not account for the external costs of fossil fuels so it is not valid. ¬†Jevons Paradox does not apply if you put a fee on the commodity, it only applies to technological advances (absent a fee) that increase the efficiency of the utilization of a commodity.

Oil prices are dropping now so it is the perfect time to implement Fee and Dividend. ¬†Renewables are a small percent of the energy system now, but they can scale up quickly. ¬†Germany put incentives in places and now 20~30% of its electricity comes from renewables. ¬†It can be done but we need to get moving urgently.
author: Climate Chat Club

text:
¬†@Dan Miller¬†¬†Given that we probably only have 20 or so years left of life in general on this planet, i agree that we should get moving on Our Big Challenge.¬†
I hope there are stragglers and survivors around the world, whether underground or wherever it's safe from drought, wildfires, and misplaced, melted Arctic and Antarctic glacier water floods.¬†
Whatever toys we create by that stage will be available for the picking of anyone left around to enjoy them. And, the sooner we reduce impacts, the sooner any of their surviving offspring can start to enjoy the climate AND the weather again, given another couple of thousand years' restabilisation.¬†
author: Andrew White

text: ¬†@*****¬† In my opinion, we should drastically reevaluate Nuclear Energy. It's the only real solution we have today to keep our energy and to not pollute the air. All fossil fuel burning will have to stop.We need to sex up the image people have of nuclear energy.
author: Cinqmil

text:
''sex up'' mass exposure to radiation, ie. ever higher rates of cancer in ever younger members of your local neighbourhood? Oh good grief.¬†
¬†- I personally know two young women (one about 35, the other about 25) who now bear scars over their throats from having their thyroid glands removed over the last few years, and that's here upwind of Fukushima, in South Korea.
Cancer is a huge growth industry here (pardon the unintended pun) with increasing numbers of people of all ages now needing to visit fancy expensive shiny new local and national cancer specialist hospitals. Cancer in kids (high school or younger) in Japan and the west coast of the US has sky rocketed in the last few years. And given the huge daily outpouring of radioactive water into the Pacific ever since the original tsunami knocked out most of the Fukushima reactors, have you wondered why so many seal pups are turning up dead or starving on the south east coast of the US recently, and why so many starfish suddenly have issues with not dissolving to the touch? - Okay, granted, these last two could be results from other effects more directly related to ocean acidification or other aspects of global warming; however, food from Turkey and other countries downwind of the Ukraine (ie. Chernobyl) still have higher rates of radioactivity than is normal or, indeed, safe, and Fukushima is already many, many times way worse than Chernobyl ever was.
Is this the future you want more of?! Is this the reality you want to somehow miraculously 'make sexy' - ?! Wow. Maybe you should get a job selling or promoting cigarettes, meat, or dairy products, or something equally disgusting and deadly. Maybe you already do have such a job?
- For more on any of those kinds of extremely unsexy but simple facts, search for, and read, pretty much anything by Helen Caldicott. ‚Ä¶ (Or, anyone else NOT paid directly by the corrupt a-holes who actually run or help promote the nuclear industry.) Another such great example is the late and very great Hermann Scheer, the granddaddy of the German solar industry. The beautiful guy was both a scientist and a reluctant though determined politician, who knew, understood, and wrote about both the solar and nuclear industries. He often explained just how corrupt the latter was, while also pointing out just how under utilised the huge potential of the solar industry was.
author: Andrew White

text:
¬†@Julian Warmington¬†
¬†Yes, but nuclear energy is 'cleaner' energy than fossil fuels. IF we want to hold on to our daily energy use, we will eventually have to turn to nuclear energy. I used to think that we, humans, would be able to drastically head into a new direction, but I'm not that optimistic anymore after reading a lot of 'climate denial'.

It seems people would rather hang on to their luxury than to their 'children and grandchildren's future. It seems plausible that if we choose nuclear energy and stop the burning of fossil fuels, that at least we have somewhat protected that future, without sacrificing too much in the short term.

I'm not a salesman. I'm just pointing out that if we have to choose between nuclear energy and the burning of fossil fuels, we should opt for the nuclear energy. Today nuclear energy is the only option to keep our recent 'luxury' standard of energy use. In the future that might change, but we shouldn't practice wishfull thinking. Imho nuclear energy is the only short term solution we have against the burning of fossil fuels.

And time is ticking away!

text: Draciron: ¬†Fee and Dividend (F&D) is anti-regressive in that the poor and middle class make more money on the dividend than they pay in higher prices, so no freezing to death, etc. ¬†Also, the Border Tax Adjustment (import tariff) protects American industry and encourages other countries to put a price on carbon. ¬†Without dramatic reductions in GLOBAL emissions, we are all screwed and the ones who will be screwed the most are the poor in other countries... the people you say you want to protect. ¬†As I point out in the talk, an economic analysis of F&D shows it will create 2.8 million jobs in the U.S. and grow GDP by $1.4 trillion. ¬†
author: Dan Miller

text: Excellent cogent and compelling presentation Dan! Especially enjoyed the slides on psycho/sociological cultural reasons for denial. Knew some, but was not aware of all, the subliminal forces at work against taking action. The only thing I would add is that in addition to asking people to talk to family, friends, etc. we need a strong presence in mainstream broadcast media (Radio/TV - my professional background) to discuss all the issues, urgency and solutions. Currently the ONLY dedicated programming on mass media outlets is from those working actively AGAINST progress -- Fox TV and radio hosts, backed by Koch and company (fossil fuel money), etc. As long as we don't have the other side on as regularly -- five days a week, several hours a day, we will never win this battle. I am willing to bet my life, money and career on this, and in fact have. The missing media piece is a BIG part of the problem and I wish more could see that!! Thx.

text:
The tricky part is moving our government. Perhaps you've noticed that our politicians are the best that money can buy, doing the bidding of exploitative corporations that don't share our priorities. While I support a revenue neutral carbon tax, I'm not going to wait for the US government. Perhaps my state government will move in that direction, but even they are beholden to fossil fuel donors.

Meanwhile, my community is moving toward a fossil fuel free future. We're getting out of cars, consuming a lot less, and building up a local democracy to protect our right to choose a sensible life without corporate influence. We're learning to grow our own food, pedal our own bikes, and care for our neighbors.
author: Vernon Huffman

text: Thank you, Dan! What a no-brainer the revenue-neutral carbon fee and dividend is, and it's exactly what Citizens' Climate Lobby is working towards. Their proposal just won the popular choice award at MIT's contest for a US Carbon Price. Learn more at¬†http://climatecolab.org/web/guest/plans/-/plans/contestId/1300404/planId/2802
author: peter joseph

text:
Whenever I hear the idea of tax & dividend, the folk song 'This Land is Your Land' plays in the back of my head‚Ä¶..
It's beautifully elegant: Each citizen is treated as an equal shareholder in the atmosphere, mirroring the fact that every citizen is already equal stakeholders in the atmosphere.
AND it's already been done in the US by that bastion of socialism, Alaska: The Alaska Permanent Fund reinvests taxes on oil and returns an annual dividend to each citizen of the state. In recent years it's been between $900 and $1800 per person.

author: V E

text: Rick Knight I disagree, the way to fight this as proposed by this video would not work and it is certainly not upheld by "most economists" as an economist myself from the UK, I can tell you this strategy holds absolutely no value in economic theory. As you tax the corporations, they pass that tax onto the consumer (as identified by the gentlemen). However if you then subsidise that consumer then demand goes up and becomes less elastic ( meaning people's demand will respond less than  proportionally to a change in price). As the corporations will not feel the burn of the tax, And demand increases, profit for the firms will likely increase as well as demand, a new market equilibrium will be reached with a greater price and demand and supply. The burning of fossil fuels will only increase with this strategy. My next reply will contain my own view on how we solve this issue.
author: dylan holder

text: Rick Knight As identified in my first comment, I believe there is a better and more efficient way to protect and conserve the environment. It takes shape in the expansion, development and implementation of property rights. When someone owns something, they have a high incentive to look after it, the best example of this would be the comparison between public and private industries, be it education, healthcare etc. In these circumstances the private alternative is almost always more efficient, better quality and thus looked after better. If property rights were developed in such a way that you didn't just own your house, But the air around it to, and the local lake was not public, But someone owned that to, then pollution becomes impossible without suffering a law suit. If you pollute the air around my house, and I fall I'll as a result, then I have a pretty strong case against you the polluter. If you dump toxic waste in a stream that leads to my owned section of the river and incidentally my fish die and my water becomes useless, then I can sue you the polluter for damages. In this system, pollution would become extremely inefficient for businesses, therefore the continuation of such pollution would be considerably less likely.

text:
¬†@birchual¬†¬† While corporate government is part of the problem, so are the psychological barriers that I (partially) mention in my talk. ¬†The plan itself is bipartisan. ¬†A similar plan is in place in conservative Alaska (the Alaska Permanent Fund) and everyone loves it. ¬†Don't forget that climate change impacts are occurring now, are being noticed, and will accelerate in the coming years, so this is something that will be harder and harder to ignore. ¬†

Another problem is that no one wants to pay costs now to solve a future problem. ¬†But Fee and Dividend creates jobs and grows the economy, so its much easier to implement. ¬†But we need to get everyone talking about it. ¬†It will happen eventually. ¬†The trick is to make it happen soon.
author: Dan Miller

text: ¬†@Dan Miller¬† What are the impacts that are occurring now?¬†There have been statements of predictions made that are the exact opposite and other CC claims that all scientists say¬†are natural events. All projections of wind and solar even with subsidy's are failures. And geo engineering wants to make the planet colder negating the overall advances of solar today. The current CC claim is that CO2 is the problem mainly because all other gases cannot be directly related to man. The worlds atmosphere of CO2 is .038% and the NOAA and IPCC claim we contribute 7% of that figure, so how are humans responsible? Your "No Fee" plan fails because no company is not going to absorb any loss themselves, their products will cost more to consume. On top of that if you make it harder for any country to sell here they will not sell here and those products prices on what we can get will go up, or they will sell it to sell to us from another country. You will lose more jobs, make everything more expensive and start wars. Go back to the think tank and try again. I am trying to stay away from a debate about the CC reports but I think that is part of your problem of understanding that humans are not causing global warming and the big cats like Gore are crying wolf to become rich. And to think the oil companies are against the GW idea is ridicules because they¬†have anticipated making more money¬†either way.¬†
author: michael costa

text:
¬†@michael costa¬†¬†You have your facts mixed up. ¬†The predictions of climate scientists, if anything, have underestimated the speed and severity of climate change impacts. ¬†The atmospheric CO2 concentration is now 0.04% but it used to be 0.028% in the late 1800's. ¬†The 43% increase is due almost entirely to human activities (burning fossil fuels, deforestation, etc.). ¬†You are correct that companies will pass on the fee by raising prices but that is the goal of the policy! ¬†If prices go up, people will use less fossil fuels and find alternatives.

Since the "external" costs of fossil fuels are real and must be paid by all of us (through higher insurance costs and taxes, for example), putting a price on fossil fuels will make our economy run more efficiently and actually increase our standard of living compared to what it will otherwise be.

Failing to address climate change will certainly lead to more wars, more climate refugees, and a lower standard of living for all.
author: Climate Chat Club

text:
¬†@Dan Miller¬†¬†The alternatives to nuclear, coal and natural gas like wind and solar are not a viable solution. The models all are geared to prove that CO2 is the problem. The norm of CO2 is just under 300ppm, that means man makes up 1/4 of CO2 in the world. That in itself is not man made. But lets put it in another perspective. 400 out of 1,000,000 is a drop in the bucket. 100 out of 1,000,000 is even less of a drop. text:
The rising fee on CO2 will make fossil fuel more expensive and, therefore, less competitive with clean energy alternatives. ¬†More expensive fossil fuels will also make conservation and efficiency more worthwhile. ¬†For example, in Europe, where gas prices are about twice what they are in the US, the average automobile fuel efficiency is much higher than in the US. ¬†Europeans have a high standard of living but their average carbon footprint is about half that of an American.

Besides individual incentives, the rising fee on CO2 will cause power plant operators to stop building coal plants (and eventually natural gas plants as well) because they know that the cost of fuel (including the fee) will rise over time and make the plants non-competitive.

author: Ron_the_Skeptic

text: ¬†@Ron_the_Skeptic¬† "the correct amount of CO2 is a minimum of 1600 ppm and a maximum of 10,000 ppm.  Below 1600 ppm plants are starved.  Above 1%, or 10,000 ppm, humans with compromised respiratory systems may have trouble breathing."..........How did you arrive at these numbers?
author: Chris Thompson

text:
¬†@Chris Thompson¬†, my first thought on seeing your post was "Huh?  I provided a rational!"
However, here is a bit more detail:  
The 1% number comes from a mine safety chart.  Less than 1% CO2 is acceptable for virtually everyone.  2% causes many people to have shortness of breath.  5% kills those in the mine. 
1600 ppm or 0.16% comes from practices in commercial greenhouses which pump CO2 into their buildings to improve plant growth.  Perhaps the 1600 number should be higher and 1600 ppm is all greenhouses are willing to pay for in the interest of promoting growth and saving water.  They are in business to generate income and CO2 is an expense.
It is pretty clear from this graph that long ago there was between 5% and 8% CO2 in the atmosphere and that level has reduced to almost nothing, about 180 ppm, during the more recent glaciations. Plants start to die at 150 ppm.  If plants die, we die.  It is also clearly evident that, over 600 million years, temperature has moved quite independently of CO2 and that even 5% or more atmospheric CO2 does not cause some bizarre run-away temperature increase.

Hope that more fully addresses your question.
author: Ron_the_Skeptic
